urn:contentItem:5TSP-K701-JBHT-D2PR-00000-00Rising Trade Tensions; Democrats' Economic Message; Trump on Kelly and Nielsen; Trouble for Nissan; Watching Tech Stocks; Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations 'Inevitable'; Secret Santa at Wal-Mart; White House Christmas Tree; Da Bomb Now has Major Partnerships with Costco and Target2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:03ZLexisNexisRising Trade Tensions; Democrats' Economic Message; Trump on Kelly and Nielsen; Trouble for Nissan; Watching Tech Stocks; Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations 'Inevitable'; Secret Santa at Wal-Mart; White House Christmas Tree; Da Bomb Now has Major Partnerships with Costco and TargetLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: The futures are under pressure this morning, coming off a week of losses, an 85-point loss on the Dow futures. The selling picking up a little bit of steam as we move closer to the opening bell a little more than two and-a-half hours from now.

This after a week of red for all your major market indicators. Dow and Nasdaq falling more than 2 percent last week. The S&P down 1.6 percent.

In Europe we had a little bit of buying earlier in the session. But now the CAC 40 in France and the DAX have dipped into negative territory.

Asian markets finishing higher overnight. All four major markets there to the plus side.

Trouble for Nissan, Japan's NHK reporting that chairman Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. The automaker looking to remove him as chairman.

And a rough road for Apple, CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation but he says it is coming anyway. The tech giant already struggling with orders for its new iPhones. Suppliers are paying the price. We break down all of that for you.

And leaving the crew -- why the CEO J Crew is leaving the company ahead of the holiday season after only being in the position for a little more than a year.

Here with me this morning: Fox Business' Susan Li, along with "Wall Street Journal" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, and pollster and Maslansky & Partners president Lee Carter. Welcome, one and all. What's on your mind?

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Well, this trade issue where the Chinese will not -- the Chinese government, I should say -- will not even agree to the idea that we shouldn't have unfair trade practices. We've seen how in the past they've refused to acknowledge intellectual property theft. Now they're not even willing to endorse as a general principle that we ought to have open, fair trading relationship. Very bizarre.

But maybe it's just setting the table. Maybe this is art of the deal and then they'll be more reasonable later. I don't know.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: But I'm scare when you're using the term "cold war". This is a new cold war and it's been opened in 2018. And they're calling chaos at APEC. I mean they've never seen this before. And it's usually a friendly display of relations between all the countries.

So this is something that President Trump and the administration is shaking up. And we'll see how it works.

MCDOWELL: Let me just raise this issue though, what is better -- acting like everyone gets along and essentially lying? Like oh, we love each other.

FREEMAN: Yes.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: Isn't that what diplomacy is?

MCDOWELL: Or actually like let's crack this egg and just show the world what's really going on.

CARTER: Right. I think it's really fascinating too that people are willing to be patient with this process. Like I've been having some conversation with some farmers and ranchers, in some of the work that we do. They are willing to stick it out and say we're going to -- you know, it's worth it in the long term for us to take some pain now. And I think that's a fascinating thing that we haven't really seen before.

MCDOWELL: We can continue this conversation because we've got Anthony Scaramucci on deck.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: He's raring to go.

American and Chinese trade tensions spilling over -- we were talking about this. Economic giants sparring at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit. China reportedly upset over the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices. This is the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which a communique was not issued.

Here now, former White House communications director, SkyBridge Capital founder, author of "The Blue Collar President" -- Anthony Scaramucci --

ANTHONY SCARAMUCCI, FOUNDER, SKYBRIDGE CAPITAL: Practicing my APEC wave here.

MCDOWELL: -- no. If you're going to do the wave, we need to teach you the -- it's the light bulb, it's screwing in the light bulb. There you go.

SCARAMUCCI: Good, good. I need shoulder surgery. But go ahead. I'm sorry.

MCDOWELL: Your reaction -- China, the United States. Where do we go from here in terms of the trade relationship?

SCARAMUCCI: So I'm going to say something outrageous. I actually think that they're going to get a deal done pretty quickly. And if it's not next week, it will be before the end of the year because that's the President's personality.

And if you go back to the Canadian-Mexican deal, and you look at the concessions that were made that were minor concessions. And so this has typically been the President's style.

He is very rough in the beginning. He comes out guns a-blazing. He's boxing away. If you read "The Art of the Deal", that's exactly what he does. And then he tries to meet in the middle towards the end of the negotiation.

And so here's another thing for the President. I know his personality well enough to know that he wants this thing done by latest the end of January because he's got to set up the narrative going into the back half of his administration that he's tied up these trade deals. And then he'll want to work on an immigration or an infrastructure deal with the Democrats.

LI: So Anthony I hosted APEC in 2014 and my sources are telling me --

SCARAMUCCI: Were you doing this?

LI: Well, you know, working on it, at great risk. Great risk --

(CROSSTALK)

LI: -- because of it. But basically from my sources in Asia, they said that they were insulted that President Trump didn't even make the trip to Papua New Guinea. So that was already, you know, laying the ground work by not showing respect.

And that might may be a good negotiating tactic as well because at least you're sending a message to the rest of Asia, particularly China, aren't you?

SCARAMUCCI: Well, I mean -- you know, that could be. I think it's a combination of different things. Just the unbelievable schedule that he had leading up into the midterms. I think that they probably held him back from going to Asia.

But I don't really think that should be something that should be insulting anybody. I think what, you know, the Americans are upset about are the IP situation with China and so it appears that there are going to be concessions made there on behalf of the U.S. and so that's where I think the trade deal gets done. But I don't think anybody should be upset that he didn't make it to APEC.

FREEMAN: Ok. So we've talked a lot about the President's time line. And this is really good news that this is not going to be sort of a permanent fight with the Chinese in your view. That he's looking to wrap it up.

How about on the Chinese side? There's this sense that China thinks in decades or centuries but I think there's some pressure on Xi Jinping to deal as well.

SCARAMUCCI: I absolutely think that. If you know where their market is Jim, and you look at where the currency is right now, both of those things are true. And I think one of the things that gets overstated by the western media is the overall strength of the Chinese economy.

Like, if you look at their level three assets, if you're a banking analyst and you're examining their level three assets, it's really the core of the capital structure of the Chinese commercial banking system, they never wrote down those assets after 2008.

And so those assets are wildly overstated which has a big impact on the Chinese government. It puts pressure on their reserves as they try to prop up those banks. And what you don't want is a material slowdown where you see the GDP of China dipping below 6.5 percent because that puts them in a danger zone as it relates to the mass urbanization that's taking place throughout China.

So I absolutely think this is pressure on both sides and I think that the President likes -- I think both presidents like each other. So my guess is this thing will get done. If not next week, shortly thereafter.

MCDOWELL: Anthony here is incoming House Republican Conference chair Liz Cheney commenting on the Democrats' economic message yesterday with Maria on "SUNDAY MORNING FUTURES" on Fox. So listen to this. I want to get your reaction.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LIZ CHENEY (R-WY), CONGRESSWOMAN-ELECT: The Democrats right now are focused on this so-called Russia collusion, the Russia threat. I think the real Russia threat, Maria, is when you look at the kind of Soviet style economic policy that the Democrats in particular, some of the freshmen coming in are advocating.

So I think the Democrats are going through a very challenging time. And Nancy Pelosi is working very hard to try to become the next speaker which means that she's got to kowtow in many ways to that wing of her party. That's not good for the country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: President Trump offered to help Nancy Pelosi basically get the speakership.

SCARAMUCCI: As many votes as she needs. As many votes as she needs.

MCDOWELL: Every time I read that, I just laugh out loud. Because it -- it seems like he's really throwing shade which makes me chuckle.

SCARAMUCCI: Well, he's throwing shade in one way but in another way she may need the votes. And by the way, she's going to be the speaker.

So they can say whatever they want. And they can posture any way that they want. She's an absolutely ruthless killer. I say that in the most complementary, most admirable way.

MCDOWELL: Not literally.

SCARAMUCCI: No, I'm saying metaphorically. But I mean she's (INAUDIBLE) in. She's definitely going to be the House Speaker. So -- and by the way, I have an 11-day PhD in this nonsense that goes down in Washington, ok.

So I'm telling you -- you know, I'm telling you right now, the knives are being sharpened metaphorically. And she is going to be the House Speaker. So do you want me to comment on what Representative Cheney was saying or you'd rather not?

MCDOWELL: Money talks and mmm walks whether you're in Washington or anywhere else in the country. And ultimately she is one of the greatest fundraisers in modern Democratic history.

SCARAMUCCI: And by the way, I mean you have to give her a lot of credit for the midterm elections. She raised a ton of money and she mobilized people in the right areas.

And you know, you can call it a blue wave, a minor blue wave. It wasn't a blue ripple. If you look at the whole landscape, you look at the state legislatures and the governorships switching -- it certainly wasn't a blue ripple.

Having said that, I think without the President's help it could have been way worse.

MCDOWELL: I want to get to this -- speaking of the President. He was sounding off on the future of Homeland Security Secretary Kirstjen Nielsen and chief of staff John Kelly on Fox News with Chris Wallace yesterday. So listen to this, Anthony, and then react.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: I like her a lot. I respect her a lot. She's very smart. I want her to get much tougher and we'll see what happens there.

We get along well. There are certain things I love what he does and there are certain things that I don't like that he does -- and there are his strength (ph).

John at some point is going to want to move on. John will move on.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: When will John Kelly move on?

SCARAMUCCI: Look at me. It couldn't happen soon enough for me, right. But I'm just saying like as it relates to the President, ok, he's a lot like George Steinbrenner. So all of us that are aficionados of sports going back into the 70s and 80s known when he says we'll see what happens, that's like incoming, take cover. You follow what I'm saying.

Get under the desk and see if you can wait the thing out with him. But he said that with, you know, the attorney general. And he has said that on many different occasions. And by the way, I wasn't even there long enough for him to say let's see what happens, ok. I was gone before he could say let's see what happens.

MCDOWELL: Who's going to be the next attorney general?

SCARAMUCCI: I don't know. I mean hope it's Chris Christie. You know, I think Chris would have the President's back but also be impartial. And I see, you know, there's some --

MCDOWELL: I just made a face.

SCARAMUCCI: -- some faces here but I like Chris a lot. I mean --

MCDOWELL: There's a history with Chris Christie and Jared Kushner's father.

SCARAMUCCI: I got it. I think they've moved past that.

MCDOWELL: Ok.

SCARAMUCCI: And so -- and I think he's a great guy, Chris. And so I would like to see him because I think he would have the President's back but he would also run the department properly.

CARTER: There's this idea that the White House is sort of in disarray with all these staffing changes and all this kind of moves. Do you think all of this was underfoot before the midterms and this is just now happening? Or are there things that have recently happened that seemed to shake things up?

SCARAMUCCI: That's the thing that I don't get about this because he's an entrepreneur. He's been an entrepreneur his whole life. If you study entrepreneurship, or you take a Harvard case study on entrepreneurship, there's tremendous turnover for entrepreneurs, particularly when they're getting started in a situation.

Whether it's Jeff Bezos, Michael Dell, Bill Gates, Steven Jobs -- you can pick the entrepreneur, they're whipping through things in the beginning until they get the team right.

And I think what the President's understanding right now is that like if you were a condo guy, you hire condo builders. If you're a golf guy, you hire golf course builders. He thought ok, I going into the government, I hire government builders.

And what ended up happening there is a lot of those people were not very loyal to him or his agenda. And so now he's got to shift the deck and reshuffle the deck to people that are going to be more loyal to him.

LI: So who's going to be the chief of staff? A budget guy? Do you think it will be Mick Mulvaney?

SCARAMUCCI: I don't know. I like him a lot. I think he would be great. Somebody mentioned Nick Ayers who's the Vice President's chief of staff. I, you know, got to know him reasonably well, as well. I like him as well.

Maybe the fact that I said that I like both of those guys is the kiss of death for both of them. They're probably going to call me later and say stop talking about me on TV. You know, I don't know but I like both those guys.

FREEMAN: I mean your experience, I understand --

SCARAMUCCI: PhD.

FREEMAN: PhD -- you kind of wanted it to go a little longer than 11 days. But --

SCARAMUCCI: I thought I was going to make it longer than a carton of milk -- Jim. But, you know --

FREEMAN: Let's not get back -- I mean Kelly has done a lot of good things there. I mean --

(CROSSTALK)

SCARAMUCCI: Name one.

FREEMAN: I don't think this is a given.

SCARAMUCCI: Name one good thing that he's done.

FREEMAN: Well, for example --

SCARAMUCCI: Name one.

FREEMAN: -- this is a White House that despite all the reports of chaos has remained remarkably faithful to the President's 2016 agenda and has gotten a lot done -- when we think about judges, we think about the tax cut.

SCARAMUCCI: You're attributing that to John Kelly or to the President?

FREEMAN: I would say both of them. But I would say Kelly deserves some credit here as the chief of staff.

(CROSSTALK)

SCARAMUCCI: We'll see the aftermath of this whole thing -- what really comes out, ok. I mean you read Bob Woodward's book, so did I. So we're going to see --

MCDOWELL: I did.

SCARAMUCCI: -- the aftermath of this whole thing.

MCDOWELL: No. Because I want to -- that's the narrative.

SCARAMUCCI: He hasn't been fair to the President. I mean just read what he talks about -- read what he says about the President.

MCDOWELL: But that's the narrative that the President somehow needs a minder, somebody who teaches him how to close doors to the Oval Office. And I think that people who know the President push back on that.

SCARAMUCCI: I pushed back on that very hard, ok. And I don't even care that John fired me. That's ridiculous. That won't be the last time I've been fired. It wasn't the first time that I've been fired, ok. I'm a bit of a renegade so I expect to be fired again in the future.

But here's the bottom line, ok. He hurt the morale inside the White House, ok. And he's got a mercurial, militant sort of nature to his personality and he's pushed a lot of people out that were very valuable to the President.

Forget about me. Let's say that I wasn't. but I'm just talking about other people inside the White House.

FREEMAN: But in large part isn't this the job of the chief of staff?

SCARAMUCCI: They're playing the music, brother. See that? I'm going to get out of here. We're going to get through a commercial break.

MCDOWELL: I had so much more I wanted to ask you about.

(CROSSTALK)

SCARAMUCCI: Before I leave though -- Susan, how am I doing with the wave?

LI: Make a twist, more wrist action.

SCARAMUCCI: I just want to make sure. Ok.

MCDOWELL: Scaramucci -- we don't use first names -- holding back.

SCARAMUCCI: Holding back.

MCDOWELL: Carlos Ghosn -- an overnight arrest. More when we come back.

(CROSSTALK)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Nissan ousting Carlos Ghosn as chairman. Cheryl Casone has the details on this developing story -- Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: It is. And we're hoping to learn more in a couple of hours from now -- Dagen.

But first to this news. Carlos Ghosn is being dismissed after an internal investigation found significant acts of misconduct. Japanese media reporting Ghosn was arrested after he met with prosecutors on suspicion that he falsified his financial reports.

Japan's NHK says Nissan's representative Director Greg Kelly was also arrested. Ghosn led a dramatic turnaround in Nissan, rescuing the company from near bankruptcy. He is also chairman and chief executive of France's Renault. Shares of Nissan down about 10 percent so far this year.

Well, thousands of brokers reportedly have been allowed to scrub their records clean of complaints by customers and employers. According to a new study in the "Wall Street Journal", employees which found the practice makes it hard for regulators and consumers to watch the behavior of brokers. Discovering process overseen by FINRA which, of course, regulates the brokerages. FINRA's considering changes that's would make it harder for brokers to purge those records.

Ok. There is this. Former New York City mayor, Michael Bloomberg giving a record-breaking $1.8 billion to his alma mater -- Johns Hopkins University. It's the biggest donation ever gifted to a school. The money can allow students to be considered for admission regardless of their ability to pay.

Bloomberg says that he hopes the donation will allow Hopkins to offer more generous scholarships and ease the debt burden for graduates.

And those are your headlines. A lot of cash -- Dagen.

MCDOWELL: Yes. Enough that -- how much did he -- that's how much -- put it this way, I said this Cheryl to somebody, that like millionaires are beneath him.

CASONE: Yes, pretty much.

MCDOWELL: He has to socialize with billionaires.

CASONE: Millionaire whatever. Yes.

MCDOWELL: Just really quickly. This is money well spent. Running for president, maybe not so much.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think he's going to look at that and find that there's not a kind of natural home for his mix of moderation on economics and social liberalism.

LI: And he's one of the biggest donors for the midterms as well, on the Democratic side, obviously for Bloomberg.

MCDOWELL: Because he was -- because he well, was in favor of the tax on sugary sodas. He's very much tried to fight cost of health care through things like that.

FREEMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Very, very much in favor of gun control giving a lot of money on gun control issues. And then he's kind of fiscally conservative in some ways. He knows how to balance a budget. But that means taking things away from people.

FREEMAN: Well, you do wonder, because he does have the funds to launch an independent candidacy, whether that might be a way to go. But I just -- I don't see it.

CARTER: I don't see him being able to carry the vote but I could see him as a mastermind behind somebody's strategy and political ideology. So I don't -- I think that maybe he should be the man behind the curtain, not necessarily the man in front of the curtain -- or woman.

LI: Or a running mate potentially?

CARTER: An interesting idea, for sure.

LI: You know.

MCDOWELL: Just don't ask for like chipotle aioli with your corn dog at the Iowa State Fair. That's all I have to say.

Coming up --

FREEMAN: Always good advice.

MCDOWELL: I can -- you know, they're not great retail politicians sometimes.

Coming up, Facebook fall out. Mark Zuckerberg reportedly wants to go to war over the media's reporting of the company's disarray.

Plus retail in focus this week ahead of Black Friday sales. Why strong corporate third quarter earnings were not enough to lift investors' spirits.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Let's take a look at futures. They're pointing to a lower open on Wall Street with technology on the decline. The "Wall Street Journal" reporting this morning that more investors are looking towards stocks with slower but steadier growth -- cheaper growth.

Joining me now, S&P global market intelligence portfolio manager Erin Gibbs. Do you think that this trend continues or do people ultimately come back to technology stocks?

ERIN GIBBS, GLOBAL MARKET INTELLIGENCE PORTFOLIO MANAGER, S&P: No, we've been talking for a while about investors coming back to value stocks. There's been a change in leadership.

Even last week we really saw value pick up over these like higher-priced growth stocks. And part of that is because technology is actually going to have massively slowing growth next year. They're actually going to have below average earnings growth versus the broader market.

So people need to start looking in other areas if you're really going to look for where profits, revenues and earnings growth are going to come from as well as better valuations.

MCDOWELL: Susan -- I noticed that last week that the Dow stocks that hit all-time highs at the end of the week were Coca-Cola, McDonald's, and Procter & Gamble.

LI: Right.

MCDOWELL: That's where the money was.

LI: And investors are going into Starbucks and, you know, Bill Ackman bought a stake recently. But I was really a little shocked by reading the Goldman Sachs report this weekend. They're predicting GDP to be 3.5 percent this year -- that's the best year of growth since 2005. Next year in 2019, only close to 1.5 percent for expansion.

GIBBS: Well, part of that is because we're having such a phenomenal year this year. But it's really tough to keep up that pace. And we're even seeing that in profit growth where we're looking at about 23 percent profit growth this year and 8 percent next year. And so it's just harder and harder to grow that fast and we're having such a phenomenal year this year.

LI: But this slowdown in the economy, does that impact the markets?

GIBBS: Well, I mean that's exactly what we've been seeing for the past month-and-a-half is as we're particularly going through Q3 earnings, people start looking at 2019. It's finally on their radar and they're saying oh, wow, it's going to be really tough to grow faster next year. There's going to be slower growth.

It's still super healthy. We're not talking about a recession or anything. It's just -- it's going to be slower and you probably want to be a little more cautious about where you put your money and maybe focus on value a little.

FREEMAN: Yes. I think that does raise a question, whether people are too cautious. The markets right now, given this 20 plus percent earnings growth, the multiples are not that huge. Maybe on some of the tech names, but in general is there a lot of room for upside surprise here next year?

GIBBS: No look, right now we're trading -- we look at it as forward valuations and PEs. And we're trading at about 16 times forward earnings. That is not super cheap. That's actually in line with about your sort of three-year average.

So yes, there's room to go up. We could certainly go up, you know, 10 percent from here and still be on a very healthy valuation. But we could also go down to 15 times forward earnings and go down another 5 or 6 percent and still again be in a very healthy, normal range.

So there's a lot of possibilities around sentiment and we still say definitely evaluate the value stocks are definitely some of your safer bets for this market -- in this territory.

MCDOWELL: I just want to mention retail really quickly. A big list of companies reporting this week including Lowe's, Target, I'm looking at L. Brands, that is the -- I think they report today.

GIBBS: Victoria's Secret.

MCDOWELL: Yes. That talk about trying to grasp for relevancy there. Anyway, what are we going to see from the retail sector? Will it give us a window into what the holiday shopping season looks like.

GIBBS: Yes. This is sort of their -- the big report and what we're going to see, look for guidance for the holiday season. Right now forecast for retail for the holiday season is one of the best ever. We're looking at about a 5 percent growth, just on the earnings, obviously more of it goes to online.

What we have been seeing with retailers is those that actually make and manufacture clothing, shoes, they're getting harder hit. The people that sell it, companies like Ulta (ph) that are really able to engage the shopper, they tend to do better, as well as anybody that has a strong online presence.

And we're seeing, you know, different ways to deliver the product to consumers, not just always shipping it from home, being able to pick it up and that type of thing. So we're seeing a lot of creativity so it's going to be an interesting year. Yes, this is a very important week for those holiday sales.

MCDOWELL: The reason I took a shot as L. Brands, it's like super skinny women strutting around in badly made lingerie -- I think that's a little outdated. The modern definition of beauty is just not whatever Victoria's Secret -- Vicky's Secret is still trying to sell. Anyway, that was my two cents.

GIBBS: Agreed.

MCDOWELL: I put you on the spot -- Erin. But let's hope for a nice holiday because Nordstrom had a bad week last week.

GIBBS: Yes, they did. And they've been struggling. And they -- again, it's being able to deliver what the consumer wants and engage them. These big box retailers have really been struggling, so it's going to be a tough year.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you -- Erin. Thank you so much.

Coming up, Tim Cook issuing a major warning for big technology. Stay tuned to hear what the Apple chief had to say about the change coming to Silicon Valley.

And a real life Santa Claus spreading holiday cheer at a Vermont Walmart. That story later this hour.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Welcome back. I'm Dagen McDowell in for Maria Bartiromo. It's Monday, November 19th. Your top stories at 7:30 a.m. Eastern.

Futures pointing to a lower open this morning. 78 point loss on the Dow Futures right now, this after a week of red for the major market gauges. The Dow and NASDAQ last week both falling more than two percent. The S&P 500 down more than 1-1/2 percent.

In Europe we had a little bit of green in England and now the French markets have turned to the plus side as well. The DAX Index in Germany still slightly lower to start this week.

Asian markets finishing higher overnight, gains across the board there, the biggest winner, the Shanghai up almost one percent.

Facebook at war, why CEO Mark Zuckerberg reportedly has the company on red alert. What it could mean for the company's future and its stocks price.

And leaving the crew, the CEO of J. Crew leaving the company, being in that position for a little more than a year. We have the details. That was Susan Li going hmm.

Plus, 'tis the season, the White House preparing to celebrate for the holidays and one mystery Santa makes some shoppers very happy at a Wal-Mart in Vermont. The heart-warming story ahead.

And a fizzing success, we introduce you to two sisters who are making a splash with their own line of bath bombs. You got to stay tuned for that.

To our top story this half hour, big technology regulation, Apple's CEO Tim Cook warning that more regulation in Silicon Valley is on the horizon.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TIM COOK, CEO, APPLE: I am not a big fan of regulation. I'm a big believer in the free market. But we have to admit when the free market's not working. And it hasn't worked here. And I think it's inevitable that there will be some level of regulation.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MCDOWELL: This comes as Apple shares are in near bear market territory. Joining me now is Disruptive Tech Research founder and chief analyst, Lou Basenese. Lou, what do you make of Tim Cook's comments?

LOU BASENESE, FOUNDER AND CHIEF ANALYST, DISRUPTIVE TECH RESEARCH: Look, he's being honest like, big tech blew it. They had an opportunity to self- regulate and they didn't do it. And you know, I think it's unfair for Apple because if there's one technology company that's really looked after users' data and protected it, it's Apple. Now, you flip over to Facebook and Twitter and Snapchat, you know, their entire business models are predicated on exploiting user data. So, you know, built by association.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Well, Lou -- I mean, OK. So, yes, it's a different business model. I think we have to understand that first of all. And don't you think it's strategic also for Tim Cook to be able to go on the offensive at this point. He's -- yes, he's more of a hardware maker. Were as others sell free services, they take your data. So I think it's easy for him to say look, you know, we're holier than thou and we're probably better than Silicon Valley at this point.

BASENESE: Yes, look, I think it's definitely strategic. There's no reason to get out in front of the public and figure out how to do this. If you remember when we were talking about trade wars and tariffs Tim Cook got out there, talking about that to try and influence the president, perhaps too. And I think that's going to go on with all these big tech executives because they are such a big part of our everyday lives.

But at the same time, I do believe Apple can claim they are a little bit holier than the rest of the big tech sector and complex. They do look after our user data. Whereas Facebook, I mean, they just had a patent grant application filed that looks to predict your family demographic data based on data images and key words you use. I mean, is there no information that's not safe from Facebook? I mean, that's the kind of thrust of their business versus Apple's where they're trying to keep people from getting to your data.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: To be fair though, I mean, to say that the social media companies are using data and all of that, a little bit of fear mongering, right? Because if they're putting this together and maybe there's some benefit, people are getting the free access, maybe it's going to help them get better advertising, there is a value exchange that's happening. And we're acting a little bit like it's on the fairies and nobody has any idea what's going on.

BASENESE: No, I agree with you. There's got to be an exchange, right? You get something for free, there has to be a cost associated with that and I think you are -- you are get willing and giving up sacrificing some privacy. But who draws the boundary where that privacy ends, where your protections kick in?

So yes, it can get misconstrued as a fear mongering. But at the end of the day, people are the product for these advertising based businesses. I mean, Facebook derives 98.3 percent of the revenue from advertising, Apple is at 0.4 percent. So, you know, it's just built into that model and we have to figure out. Tim Cook said it, it didn't work. The free market didn't work here. Regulators' going to have to step in and figure out where that balance is.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Lou, James Freeman here at the Wall Street Journal. I think we could argue whether the market's working or not, but tell us about Apple's market, is that working? We've seen these reports. They didn't -- they want to share a little less information lately, suppliers getting nervous, they're not seeing the orders they'd like to see. What kind of condition is Apple in right now?

BASENESE: Listen, I think Apple's trying to find a new equilibrium. Less transparency on Wall Street is never a good thing. And you know, I think this morning, there's another report out from Wall Street Journal saying that production is getting cut on the three new iPhone models. So we've had multiple supplier data points stacking up to suggest that iPhone -- we might be at peak iPhone unit volumes.

But the key is peak iPhone doesn't mean peak profit for Apple. They're really making this pivot to show that their services business. I mean, their services business now is the size of Facebook's entire business. So it comes down to the last couple weeks of December, right? That's going to be make or break for Apple. And we're not going to get the data on whether they sold enough iPhones. And I really don't think that's as important as how much money they've made per customer and from that those services businesses.

MCDOWELL: Let's move back to Facebook, I guess.

BASENESE: OK.

MCDOWELL: Because the Wall Street Journal has a piece that details the tensions between top executives in the days following that New York times story last week. It's titled with Facebook at, quote, war, Zuckerberg adopts a more aggressive style. Here's part of it. Mr. Zuckerberg's new approach is causing unprecedented turmoil atop Facebook driving several key executives from the company. At times, it is created tensions with his long-time chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg. Lou, your take on this.

Again, where is this man's focus been? If you're running the company, he was busy crowing about learning Mandarin and then reading 25 books every year. And where -- I was talking to someone I'm very close to who works in Silicon Valley and in reaction to that New York Times story, he said have a cocktail, join the party, where have you been. That all of these -- that all of these problems that have been reported at Facebook are built into their business model and have been going on in one way, shape or form since day one.

BASENESE: Yes, focus, I don't think there's been a focus there. I mean, remember the Cambridge Analytica scandal? I mean, Zuckerberg was nowhere to be found for days. I think there's been inexcusable lack of leadership here. So look, I'm glad. If he's really genuine about going to war, it's about time. Facebook has made continuous excuses for why they've fallen short on a lot of areas, why they haven't disclosed data breaches early. It's about time from some of the leaders to step up.

MCDOWELL: But the thing that makes my head hurt James, as Susan you better get in on this, Facebook gave app developers access to not only individuals who use these apps, but to the friends of the users of these apps, for years. LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That was the business model. That's how they grew to the size that they are today and then they act like it's some big accident.

But I know that you'll say this, if you ever use Facebook, you know why do you need to know my high school that I went to and my hometown and what my home address is and why you need my phone number. At every -- at every moment in every breath they're asking for more and more and more information and people are saying OK, let me just give it to you and the service is for free. Well, it's not free. They're using your data and they're selling it essentially or making money off of your back.

FREEMAN: Yes, so I think their consumers have some responsibility here for the fact they enjoyed in many ways making this trade. But -- well, also, I think what's happening here in part and why all this focus on Facebook is that Washington and much of the media on the left side of the political spectrum has not forgiven them for their refusal to agree with the premise that Russian meddling was the decisive factor in the 2016 election.

BASENESE: Yes, look, they've yet to issue Mea culpa for that, right? And I think you're right, it's --

FREEMAN: Should they?

BASENESE: I think they should, absolutely. I mean, look, the New York Times came out; they had 50 different sources, right? Saying that this was known well in advance and what if Facebook --

FREEMAN: yes, but it would be the extent that it actually mattered in 2016.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: But maybe the reason they were not responding as aggressively is because they decided it's actually not that big a deal in this ocean of media that our customers are consuming.

BASENESE: Yes, but listen, on Wall Street, there's clear definitions of materiality. And I would tell you that every single shareholder would argue that any interference from a foreign government on a platform that has access to 1.8 billion people would absolutely be material. So that's not something for Facebook to decide on their own in the absence of the public.

MCDOWELL: James Freeman, I'm going to walk out on the plank and say this, I don't think the media would have paid attention to everything that's been going on at a Facebook over all the years and made as big of a deal about it if there hadn't been the Russia issue that they were lurking at --

FREEMAN: Why -- exactly, right?

MCDOWELL: -- that we would never know about any of this.

FREEMAN: (INAUDIBLE) Facebook's business model.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. It's a little bit rich.

LI: But I love the battle that's taking place in Silicon Valley between Tim Cook and Mark Zuckerberg. There's no love lost between those two. You know, in the New York Times report, Mark Zuckerberg basically said no one can use iPhones, everyone is switching to android after Tim Cook said that privacy is a human right and some people aren't doing it right including Facebook.

MCDOWELL: And I'll just point out in terms of regulation, these social media companies have a liability waiver in Washington for user created content because they aren't or weren't media companies but now if they are, do they get that liability waiver? That's something that congress could easily do, just pointing that out.

Thank you, Lou, Lou Basenese.

BASENESE: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you. Come back soon sir.

BASENESE Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Great conversation.

Coming up, leaving the crew, why J. Crew's CEO is out right before the holiday season's biggest shopping day.

And Christmas is coming to the White House, the holiday tree making its journey to Washington today, more coming up. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: J. Crew parting ways with its CEO and he hasn't been there long. Cheryl Casone has the details. Hi, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, quick relationship to tell you about, Dagen. James Brett has stepped down after just 17 months on the job. Brett says that he and the board couldn't agree on how the company should evolve. J. Crew now heads into the key holiday shopping season without their CEO. Four senior J. Crew execs are going to share CEO responsibilities until the company sets up a permanent management structure to appoint somebody new.

All right, kicking off the holiday season in the nation's capital right now, President Trump and the first lady Melania are going to receive the National Christmas Tree at the White House today. The nearly 20-foot tall, 800 pound Frasier fir which (INAUDIBLE) North Carolina and will be featured in the Blue Room. It's scheduled to arrive at the White House around 1:00 Eastern Time. It won't be lit up until next Wednesday however. They're going to decorate it.

All right, some lucky Wal-Mart shoppers have discovered they are on Santa's nice list. An anonymous man paid off every single item that was on lay away at a Wal-Mart store in Derby, Vermont.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He came up to the guy in front of me and said, either I'm going to pay for it now or I'm going to pay for it later. I get goose bumps, thinking that that is the true magic of Christmas, that's the Christmas spirit walking amongst us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: When asked by someone who could afford to pay for all those items, the mystery man said Santa Claus can. Store officials are not going to say how much the secret Santa spent but good for him. No bah humbug at that Wal-Mart, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I was looking to see where Newland, North Carolina was because I did not know, sadly. It's been beautiful --it's somewhere near beach mountain I think up in the mountains of North Carolina.

Coming up, two sisters partnering up and creating a successful business, all before they're old enough for college. We'll speak to these two entrepreneurs about their booming bath bomb business, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Two sisters making bank with bath bombs and all before they even enter college. Caroline and Isabel Bercaw started Da Bomb Bath Fizzers in their mom's kitchen. And revenue is expected to hit $20 million this year. Joining us now are the Da Bomb Bath Fizzers co-founders, Caroline and Isabel Bercaw. Good to see you both.

CAROLINE BERCAW, CO-FOUNDERS, DA BOMB BATH FIZZERS: Yes, you too.

MCDOWELL: How old were you when you started this business?

C. BERCAW: We were about 10 and 11. Yes, it was pretty crazy.

LI: How did it start?

C. BERCAW: Well, we wanted -- when we were younger we used bath bombs all the time. But we wanted to make our own because a lot of times it would stain the tub. And so, we decided to add a little extra something inside our bath bombs which was the surprise.

MCDOWELL: So what is the surprise inside the bath bomb?

ISABEL BERCAW, CO-FOUNDER, DA BOMB BATH FIZZERS: It could be like a toy or message on waterproof paper or even some jewelry. And it always coordinates with the name and the fragrance of the bomb. And we have bath bombs for everybody. So, we made them for boys and girls, and adults and kids a alike. Because we want to have fun.

LI: But how did you think we could turn this into a business? You were 10 and 11 years old.

C. BERCAW: Yes, we first started at a local art fairs. But then a local salon owner came by and it just happened they wanted to sell our stuff in his salon.

I. BERCAW: And I think a really big part of it was we were just kind of fearless in a sense because we were 10 and 11 and we didn't really fully understand the consequences of what could go wrong in owning a business.

MCDOWELL: Well clearly, you had a mom also who didn't say no, no, no, who didn't discourage you.

I. BERCAW: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And didn't -- who said OK, let's do this. And now, I just want to point out, your bath bombs are sold in stores nationwide, Costco, Target, just to name a couple. So it's gone beyond like the local salon owner.

C. BERCAW: Yes.

I. BERCAW: Yes. We're currently in 15,000 stores across the U.S. right now. No question that we haven't had a lot of help. You know, our parents help us and our business partners help us and everything.

MCDOWELL: So, Lee can help you. Because she is a marketing and branding wizard, if you need any free advice. Lee?

LI: Offer some.

CARTER: I would love to do that separately. But I'm curious, you said that you've had -- just there's been a lot of generosity as you've been exploring this idea on how you can grow your business. Tell us a little bit about how you've been inspired by their folks or kinds of tips that you've gotten along the way.

I. BERCAW: I think what's really inspiring is getting to talk to other people and know that they've been there as well. Because when you're starting a business it's really hard work. And there's a lot of fun as well. But there's also a lot that you may say, is this really worth it? So when you talk to somebody, understand that they've been down that road as well and that it's going to be OK, it's really nice to hear that.

LI: Yes, can I ask from a parenting perspective, how do parents develop kids that want to be entrepreneurs like you at 10 and 11?

C. BERCAW: We're so grateful our mom and our dad are both have been so supportive and just let us go with this. So, thanks mom and dad.

MCDOWELL: Are they -- are they entrepreneurs or do they work in kind of more regular jobs?

C. BERCAW: Yes, our mom has an advertising and writing background. And our dad was a consultant, business consultant before this. So they kind of work very well together.

I. BERCAW: And they inspire us every single day to work really hard and to follow in their footsteps.

LI: Are you going to go to college, both of you, do you want to go to college?

C. BERCAW: Yes.

I. BERCAW: Yes. If anything for the experience and I'd like to also look at other subjects as well, as well as business.

MCDOWELL: So these two retail -- big retail partnerships, is that Target and Costco that I was talking about?

C. BERCAW: Yes, we recently launched with Costco. We're in Ulta as well and CVS, so.

I. BERCAW: And we just got a target end cap where all these new products will be available. So, they're brand-new additions to our line.

CARTER: Really exciting.

MCDOWELL: Bless you both. And Happy holidays. A Happy Thanksgiving to both of you. Caroline and Isabel Bercaw, take care and please come back.

C. BERCAW: Thank you so much for having us.

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. Still ahead, head quarter headache, Amazon facing new pushback over the planned New York offices, even a parody on "SNL". We'll tell you more, next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: The futures are under pressure this morning, coming off a week of losses, an 85-point loss on the Dow futures. The selling picking up a little bit of steam as we move closer to the opening bell a little more than two and-a-half hours from now.

I mean, is there no information that's not safe from Facebook? I mean, that's the kind of thrust of their business versus Apple's where they're trying to keep people from getting to your data.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY + PARTNERS: To be fair though, I mean, to say that the social media companies are using data and all of that, a little bit of fear mongering, right? Because if they're putting this together and maybe there's some benefit, people are getting the free access, maybe it's going to help them get better advertising, there is a value exchange that's happening. And we're acting a little bit like it's on the fairies and nobody has any idea what's going on.

BASENESE: No, I agree with you. There's got to be an exchange, right? You get something for free, there has to be a cost associated with that and I think you are -- you are get willing and giving up sacrificing some privacy. But who draws the boundary where that privacy ends, where your protections kick in?

So yes, it can get misconstrued as a fear mongering. But at the end of the day, people are the product for these advertising based businesses. I mean, Facebook derives 98.3 percent of the revenue from advertising, Apple is at 0.4 percent. So, you know, it's just built into that model and we have to figure out. Tim Cook said it, it didn't work. The free market didn't work here. Regulators' going to have to step in and figure out where that balance is.

JAMES FREEMAN, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR: Lou, James Freeman here at the Wall Street Journal. I think we could argue whether the market's working or not, but tell us about Apple's market, is that working? We've seen these reports. They didn't -- they want to share a little less information lately, suppliers getting nervous, they're not seeing the orders they'd like to see. What kind of condition is Apple in right now?

BASENESE: Listen, I think Apple's trying to find a new equilibrium. Less transparency on Wall Street is never a good thing. And you know, I think this morning, there's another report out from Wall Street Journal saying that production is getting cut on the three new iPhone models. So we've had multiple supplier data points stacking up to suggest that iPhone -- we might be at peak iPhone unit volumes.

But the key is peak iPhone doesn't mean peak profit for Apple. They're really making this pivot to show that their services business. I mean, their services business now is the size of Facebook's entire business. So it comes down to the last couple weeks of December, right? That's going to be make or break for Apple. And we're not going to get the data on whether they sold enough iPhones. And I really don't think that's as important as how much money they've made per customer and from that those services businesses.

MCDOWELL: Let's move back to Facebook, I guess.

BASENESE: OK.

MCDOWELL: Because the Wall Street Journal has a piece that details the tensions between top executives in the days following that New York times story last week. It's titled with Facebook at, quote, war, Zuckerberg adopts a more aggressive style. Here's part of it. Mr. Zuckerberg's new approach is causing unprecedented turmoil atop Facebook driving several key executives from the company. At times, it is created tensions with his long-time chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg. Lou, your take on this.

Again, where is this man's focus been? If you're running the company, he was busy crowing about learning Mandarin and then reading 25 books every year. And where -- I was talking to someone I'm very close to who works in Silicon Valley and in reaction to that New York Times story, he said have a cocktail, join the party, where have you been. That all of these -- that all of these problems that have been reported at Facebook are built into their business model and have been going on in one way, shape or form since day one.

BASENESE: Yes, focus, I don't think there's been a focus there. I mean, remember the Cambridge Analytica scandal? I mean, Zuckerberg was nowhere to be found for days. I think there's been inexcusable lack of leadership here. So look, I'm glad. If he's really genuine about going to war, it's about time. Facebook has made continuous excuses for why they've fallen short on a lot of areas, why they haven't disclosed data breaches early. It's about time from some of the leaders to step up.

MCDOWELL: But the thing that makes my head hurt James, as Susan you better get in on this, Facebook gave app developers access to not only individuals who use these apps, but to the friends of the users of these apps, for years. LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: That was the business model. That's how they grew to the size that they are today and then they act like it's some big accident.

But I know that you'll say this, if you ever use Facebook, you know why do you need to know my high school that I went to and my hometown and what my home address is and why you need my phone number. At every -- at every moment in every breath they're asking for more and more and more information and people are saying OK, let me just give it to you and the service is for free. Well, it's not free. They're using your data and they're selling it essentially or making money off of your back.

FREEMAN: Yes, so I think their consumers have some responsibility here for the fact they enjoyed in many ways making this trade. But -- well, also, I think what's happening here in part and why all this focus on Facebook is that Washington and much of the media on the left side of the political spectrum has not forgiven them for their refusal to agree with the premise that Russian meddling was the decisive factor in the 2016 election.

BASENESE: Yes, look, they've yet to issue Mea culpa for that, right? And I think you're right, it's --

FREEMAN: Should they?

BASENESE: I think they should, absolutely. I mean, look, the New York Times came out; they had 50 different sources, right? Saying that this was known well in advance and what if Facebook --

FREEMAN: yes, but it would be the extent that it actually mattered in 2016.

(CROSSTALK)

FREEMAN: But maybe the reason they were not responding as aggressively is because they decided it's actually not that big a deal in this ocean of media that our customers are consuming.

BASENESE: Yes, but listen, on Wall Street, there's clear definitions of materiality. And I would tell you that every single shareholder would argue that any interference from a foreign government on a platform that has access to 1.8 billion people would absolutely be material. So that's not something for Facebook to decide on their own in the absence of the public.

MCDOWELL: James Freeman, I'm going to walk out on the plank and say this, I don't think the media would have paid attention to everything that's been going on at a Facebook over all the years and made as big of a deal about it if there hadn't been the Russia issue that they were lurking at --

FREEMAN: Why -- exactly, right?

MCDOWELL: -- that we would never know about any of this.

FREEMAN: (INAUDIBLE) Facebook's business model.

MCDOWELL: Yes, exactly. It's a little bit rich.

LI: But I love the battle that's taking place in Silicon Valley between Tim Cook and Mark Zuckerberg. There's no love lost between those two. You know, in the New York Times report, Mark Zuckerberg basically said no one can use iPhones, everyone is switching to android after Tim Cook said that privacy is a human right and some people aren't doing it right including Facebook.

MCDOWELL: And I'll just point out in terms of regulation, these social media companies have a liability waiver in Washington for user created content because they aren't or weren't media companies but now if they are, do they get that liability waiver? That's something that congress could easily do, just pointing that out.

Thank you, Lou, Lou Basenese.

BASENESE: Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Good to see you. Come back soon sir.

BASENESE Thank you.

MCDOWELL: Great conversation.

Coming up, leaving the crew, why J. Crew's CEO is out right before the holiday season's biggest shopping day.

And Christmas is coming to the White House, the holiday tree making its journey to Washington today, more coming up. Stay with us.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: J. Crew parting ways with its CEO and he hasn't been there long. Cheryl Casone has the details. Hi, Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes, quick relationship to tell you about, Dagen. James Brett has stepped down after just 17 months on the job. Brett says that he and the board couldn't agree on how the company should evolve. J. Crew now heads into the key holiday shopping season without their CEO. Four senior J. Crew execs are going to share CEO responsibilities until the company sets up a permanent management structure to appoint somebody new.

All right, kicking off the holiday season in the nation's capital right now, President Trump and the first lady Melania are going to receive the National Christmas Tree at the White House today. The nearly 20-foot tall, 800 pound Frasier fir which (INAUDIBLE) North Carolina and will be featured in the Blue Room. It's scheduled to arrive at the White House around 1:00 Eastern Time. It won't be lit up until next Wednesday however. They're going to decorate it.

All right, some lucky Wal-Mart shoppers have discovered they are on Santa's nice list. An anonymous man paid off every single item that was on lay away at a Wal-Mart store in Derby, Vermont.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He came up to the guy in front of me and said, either I'm going to pay for it now or I'm going to pay for it later. I get goose bumps, thinking that that is the true magic of Christmas, that's the Christmas spirit walking amongst us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: When asked by someone who could afford to pay for all those items, the mystery man said Santa Claus can. Store officials are not going to say how much the secret Santa spent but good for him. No bah humbug at that Wal-Mart, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I was looking to see where Newland, North Carolina was because I did not know, sadly. It's been beautiful --it's somewhere near beach mountain I think up in the mountains of North Carolina.

Coming up, two sisters partnering up and creating a successful business, all before they're old enough for college. We'll speak to these two entrepreneurs about their booming bath bomb business, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Two sisters making bank with bath bombs and all before they even enter college. Caroline and Isabel Bercaw started Da Bomb Bath Fizzers in their mom's kitchen. And revenue is expected to hit $20 million this year. Joining us now are the Da Bomb Bath Fizzers co-founders, Caroline and Isabel Bercaw. Good to see you both.

CAROLINE BERCAW, CO-FOUNDERS, DA BOMB BATH FIZZERS: Yes, you too.

MCDOWELL: How old were you when you started this business?

C. BERCAW: We were about 10 and 11. Yes, it was pretty crazy.

LI: How did it start?

C. BERCAW: Well, we wanted -- when we were younger we used bath bombs all the time. But we wanted to make our own because a lot of times it would stain the tub. And so, we decided to add a little extra something inside our bath bombs which was the surprise.

MCDOWELL: So what is the surprise inside the bath bomb?

ISABEL BERCAW, CO-FOUNDER, DA BOMB BATH FIZZERS: It could be like a toy or message on waterproof paper or even some jewelry. And it always coordinates with the name and the fragrance of the bomb. And we have bath bombs for everybody. So, we made them for boys and girls, and adults and kids a alike. Because we want to have fun.

LI: But how did you think we could turn this into a business? You were 10 and 11 years old.

C. BERCAW: Yes, we first started at a local art fairs. But then a local salon owner came by and it just happened they wanted to sell our stuff in his salon.

I. BERCAW: And I think a really big part of it was we were just kind of fearless in a sense because we were 10 and 11 and we didn't really fully understand the consequences of what could go wrong in owning a business.

MCDOWELL: Well clearly, you had a mom also who didn't say no, no, no, who didn't discourage you.

I. BERCAW: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And didn't -- who said OK, let's do this. And now, I just want to point out, your bath bombs are sold in stores nationwide, Costco, Target, just to name a couple. So it's gone beyond like the local salon owner.

C. BERCAW: Yes.

I. BERCAW: Yes. We're currently in 15,000 stores across the U.S. right now. No question that we haven't had a lot of help. You know, our parents help us and our business partners help us and everything.

MCDOWELL: So, Lee can help you. Because she is a marketing and branding wizard, if you need any free advice. Lee?

LI: Offer some.

CARTER: I would love to do that separately. But I'm curious, you said that you've had -- just there's been a lot of generosity as you've been exploring this idea on how you can grow your business. Tell us a little bit about how you've been inspired by their folks or kinds of tips that you've gotten along the way.

I. BERCAW: I think what's really inspiring is getting to talk to other people and know that they've been there as well. Because when you're starting a business it's really hard work. And there's a lot of fun as well. But there's also a lot that you may say, is this really worth it? So when you talk to somebody, understand that they've been down that road as well and that it's going to be OK, it's really nice to hear that.

LI: Yes, can I ask from a parenting perspective, how do parents develop kids that want to be entrepreneurs like you at 10 and 11?

C. BERCAW: We're so grateful our mom and our dad are both have been so supportive and just let us go with this. So, thanks mom and dad.

MCDOWELL: Are they -- are they entrepreneurs or do they work in kind of more regular jobs?

C. BERCAW: Yes, our mom has an advertising and writing background. And our dad was a consultant, business consultant before this. So they kind of work very well together.

I. BERCAW: And they inspire us every single day to work really hard and to follow in their footsteps.

LI: Are you going to go to college, both of you, do you want to go to college?

C. BERCAW: Yes.

I. BERCAW: Yes. If anything for the experience and I'd like to also look at other subjects as well, as well as business.

MCDOWELL: So these two retail -- big retail partnerships, is that Target and Costco that I was talking about?

C. BERCAW: Yes, we recently launched with Costco. We're in Ulta as well and CVS, so.

I. BERCAW: And we just got a target end cap where all these new products will be available. So, they're brand-new additions to our line.

CARTER: Really exciting.

MCDOWELL: Bless you both. And Happy holidays. A Happy Thanksgiving to both of you. Caroline and Isabel Bercaw, take care and please come back.

C. BERCAW: Thank you so much for having us.

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. Still ahead, head quarter headache, Amazon facing new pushback over the planned New York offices, even a parody on "SNL". We'll tell you more, next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END

urn:contentItem:5WG2-74M1-JBHT-D39P-00000-00Rising Trade Tensions; Democrats' Economic Message; Trump on Kelly and Nielsen; Trouble for Nissan; Watching Tech Stocks; Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations 'Inevitable'; Secret Santa at Wal-Mart; White House Christmas Tree; Da Bomb Now has Major Partnerships with Costco and Target2018-11-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:03ZLexisNexisRising Trade Tensions; Democrats' Economic Message; Trump on Kelly and Nielsen; Trouble for Nissan; Watching Tech Stocks; Apple CEO Tim Cook Says Some Level of Tech Regulations 'Inevitable'; Secret Santa at Wal-Mart; White House Christmas Tree; Da Bomb Now has Major Partnerships with Costco and TargetLanhamFULL TEXT

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: The futures are under pressure this morning, coming off a week of losses, an 85-point loss on the Dow futures. The selling picking up a little bit of steam as we move closer to the opening bell a little more than two and-a-half hours from now.

This after a week of red for all your major market indicators. Dow and Nasdaq falling more than 2 percent last week. The S&P down 1.6 percent.

In Europe we had a little bit of buying earlier in the session. But now the CAC 40 in France and the DAX have dipped into negative territory.

Asian markets finishing higher overnight. All four major markets there to the plus side.

Trouble for Nissan, Japan's NHK reporting that chairman Carlos Ghosn has been arrested for alleged financial violations. The automaker looking to remove him as chairman.

And a rough road for Apple, CEO Tim Cook speaking out against regulation but he says it is coming anyway. The tech giant already struggling with orders for its new iPhones. Suppliers are paying the price. We break down all of that for you.

And leaving the crew -- why the CEO J Crew is leaving the company ahead of the holiday season after only being in the position for a little more than a year.

Here with me this morning: Fox Business' Susan Li, along with "Wall Street Journal" assistant editorial page editor James Freeman, and pollster and Maslansky & Partners president Lee Carter. Welcome, one and all. What's on your mind?

JAMES FREEMAN, ASSISTANT EDITORIAL PAGE EDITOR, "WALL STREET JOURNAL": Well, this trade issue where the Chinese will not -- the Chinese government, I should say -- will not even agree to the idea that we shouldn't have unfair trade practices. We've seen how in the past they've refused to acknowledge intellectual property theft. Now they're not even willing to endorse as a general principle that we ought to have open, fair trading relationship. Very bizarre.

But maybe it's just setting the table. Maybe this is art of the deal and then they'll be more reasonable later. I don't know.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: But I'm scare when you're using the term "cold war". This is a new cold war and it's been opened in 2018. And they're calling chaos at APEC. I mean they've never seen this before. And it's usually a friendly display of relations between all the countries.

So this is something that President Trump and the administration is shaking up. And we'll see how it works.

MCDOWELL: Let me just raise this issue though, what is better -- acting like everyone gets along and essentially lying? Like oh, we love each other.

FREEMAN: Yes.

LEE CARTER, PRESIDENT, MASLANSKY & PARTNERS: Isn't that what diplomacy is?

MCDOWELL: Or actually like let's crack this egg and just show the world what's really going on.

CARTER: Right. I think it's really fascinating too that people are willing to be patient with this process. Like I've been having some conversation with some farmers and ranchers, in some of the work that we do. They are willing to stick it out and say we're going to -- you know, it's worth it in the long term for us to take some pain now. And I think that's a fascinating thing that we haven't really seen before.

MCDOWELL: We can continue this conversation because we've got Anthony Scaramucci on deck.

LI: Yes.

MCDOWELL: He's raring to go.

American and Chinese trade tensions spilling over -- we were talking about this. Economic giants sparring at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Summit. China reportedly upset over the wording of a phrase they viewed as unfairly singling out their trade practices. This is the first time in the summit's nearly three-decade history in which a communique was not issued.

Here now, former White House communications director, SkyBridge Capital founder, author of "The Blue Collar President" -- Anthony Scaramucci --

ANTHONY SCARAMUCCI, FOUNDER, SKYBRIDGE CAPITAL: Practicing my APEC wave here.

MCDOWELL: -- no. If you're going to do the wave, we need to teach you the -- it's the light bulb, it's screwing in the light bulb. There you go.

SCARAMUCCI: Good, good. I need shoulder surgery. But go ahead. I'm sorry.

MCDOWELL: Your reaction -- China, the United States. Where do we go from here in terms of the trade relationship?

SCARAMUCCI: So I'm going to say something outrageous. I actually think that they're going to get a deal done pretty quickly. And if it's not next week, it will be before the end of the year because that's the President's personality.

And if you go back to the Canadian-Mexican deal, and you look at the concessions that were made that were minor concessions. And so this has typically been the President's style.

He is very rough in the beginning. He comes out guns a-blazing. He's boxing away. If you read "The Art of the Deal", that's exactly what he does. And then he tries to meet in the middle towards the end of the negotiation.

And so here's another thing for the President. I know his personality well enough to know that he wants this thing done by latest the end of January because he's got to set up the narrative going into the back half of his administration that he's tied up these trade deals. And then he'll want to work on an immigration or an infrastructure deal with the Democrats.

LI: So Anthony I hosted APEC in 2014 and my sources are telling me --

SCARAMUCCI: Were you doing this?

LI: Well, you know, working on it, at great risk. Great risk --

(CROSSTALK)

LI: -- because of it. But basically from my sources in Asia, they said that they were insulted that President Trump didn't even make the trip to Papua New Guinea. So that was already, you know, laying the ground work by not showing respect.

And that might may be a good negotiating tactic as well because at least you're sending a message to the rest of Asia, particularly China, aren't you?

SCARAMUCCI: Well, I mean -- you know, that could be. I think it's a combination of different things. Just the unbelievable schedule that he had leading up into the midterms. I think that they probably held him back from going to Asia.

But I don't really think that should be something that should be insulting anybody. I think what, you know, the Americans are upset about are the IP situation with China and so it appears that there are going to be concessions made there on behalf of the U.S. and so that's where I think the trade deal gets done. But I don't think anybody should be upset that he didn't make it to APEC.

FREEMAN: Ok. So we've talked a lot about the President's time line. And this is really good news that this is not going to be sort of a permanent fight with the Chinese in your view. That he's looking to wrap it up.

How about on the Chinese side? There's this sense that China thinks in decades or centuries but I think there's some pressure on Xi Jinping to deal as well.

SCARAMUCCI: I absolutely think that. If you know where their market is Jim, and you look at where the currency is right now, both of those things are true. And I think one of the things that gets overstated by the western media is the overall strength of the Chinese economy.

Like, if you look at their level three assets, if you're a banking analyst and you're examining their level three assets, it's really the core of the capital structure of the Chinese commercial banking system, they never wrote down those assets after 2008.

And so those assets are wildly overstated which has a big impact on the Chinese government. It puts pressure on their reserves as they try to prop up those banks. All right, kicking off the holiday season in the nation's capital right now, President Trump and the first lady Melania are going to receive the National Christmas Tree at the White House today. The nearly 20-foot tall, 800 pound Frasier fir which (INAUDIBLE) North Carolina and will be featured in the Blue Room. It's scheduled to arrive at the White House around 1:00 Eastern Time. It won't be lit up until next Wednesday however. They're going to decorate it.

All right, some lucky Wal-Mart shoppers have discovered they are on Santa's nice list. An anonymous man paid off every single item that was on lay away at a Wal-Mart store in Derby, Vermont.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: He came up to the guy in front of me and said, either I'm going to pay for it now or I'm going to pay for it later. I get goose bumps, thinking that that is the true magic of Christmas, that's the Christmas spirit walking amongst us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: When asked by someone who could afford to pay for all those items, the mystery man said Santa Claus can. Store officials are not going to say how much the secret Santa spent but good for him. No bah humbug at that Wal-Mart, Dagen.

MCDOWELL: I was looking to see where Newland, North Carolina was because I did not know, sadly. It's been beautiful --it's somewhere near beach mountain I think up in the mountains of North Carolina.

Coming up, two sisters partnering up and creating a successful business, all before they're old enough for college. We'll speak to these two entrepreneurs about their booming bath bomb business, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

MCDOWELL: Two sisters making bank with bath bombs and all before they even enter college. Caroline and Isabel Bercaw started Da Bomb Bath Fizzers in their mom's kitchen. And revenue is expected to hit $20 million this year. Joining us now are the Da Bomb Bath Fizzers co-founders, Caroline and Isabel Bercaw. Good to see you both.

CAROLINE BERCAW, CO-FOUNDERS, DA BOMB BATH FIZZERS: Yes, you too.

MCDOWELL: How old were you when you started this business?

C. BERCAW: We were about 10 and 11. Yes, it was pretty crazy.

LI: How did it start?

C. BERCAW: Well, we wanted -- when we were younger we used bath bombs all the time. But we wanted to make our own because a lot of times it would stain the tub. And so, we decided to add a little extra something inside our bath bombs which was the surprise.

MCDOWELL: So what is the surprise inside the bath bomb?

ISABEL BERCAW, CO-FOUNDER, DA BOMB BATH FIZZERS: It could be like a toy or message on waterproof paper or even some jewelry. And it always coordinates with the name and the fragrance of the bomb. And we have bath bombs for everybody. So, we made them for boys and girls, and adults and kids a alike. Because we want to have fun.

LI: But how did you think we could turn this into a business? You were 10 and 11 years old.

C. BERCAW: Yes, we first started at a local art fairs. But then a local salon owner came by and it just happened they wanted to sell our stuff in his salon.

I. BERCAW: And I think a really big part of it was we were just kind of fearless in a sense because we were 10 and 11 and we didn't really fully understand the consequences of what could go wrong in owning a business.

MCDOWELL: Well clearly, you had a mom also who didn't say no, no, no, who didn't discourage you.

I. BERCAW: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And didn't -- who said OK, let's do this. And now, I just want to point out, your bath bombs are sold in stores nationwide, Costco, Target, just to name a couple. So it's gone beyond like the local salon owner.

C. BERCAW: Yes.

I. BERCAW: Yes. We're currently in 15,000 stores across the U.S. right now. No question that we haven't had a lot of help. You know, our parents help us and our business partners help us and everything.

MCDOWELL: So, Lee can help you. Because she is a marketing and branding wizard, if you need any free advice. Lee?

LI: Offer some.

CARTER: I would love to do that separately. But I'm curious, you said that you've had -- just there's been a lot of generosity as you've been exploring this idea on how you can grow your business. Tell us a little bit about how you've been inspired by their folks or kinds of tips that you've gotten along the way.

I. BERCAW: I think what's really inspiring is getting to talk to other people and know that they've been there as well. Because when you're starting a business it's really hard work. And there's a lot of fun as well. But there's also a lot that you may say, is this really worth it? So when you talk to somebody, understand that they've been down that road as well and that it's going to be OK, it's really nice to hear that.

LI: Yes, can I ask from a parenting perspective, how do parents develop kids that want to be entrepreneurs like you at 10 and 11?

C. BERCAW: We're so grateful our mom and our dad are both have been so supportive and just let us go with this. So, thanks mom and dad.

MCDOWELL: Are they -- are they entrepreneurs or do they work in kind of more regular jobs?

C. BERCAW: Yes, our mom has an advertising and writing background. And our dad was a consultant, business consultant before this. So they kind of work very well together.

I. BERCAW: And they inspire us every single day to work really hard and to follow in their footsteps.

LI: Are you going to go to college, both of you, do you want to go to college?

C. BERCAW: Yes.

I. BERCAW: Yes. If anything for the experience and I'd like to also look at other subjects as well, as well as business.

MCDOWELL: So these two retail -- big retail partnerships, is that Target and Costco that I was talking about?

C. BERCAW: Yes, we recently launched with Costco. We're in Ulta as well and CVS, so.

I. BERCAW: And we just got a target end cap where all these new products will be available. So, they're brand-new additions to our line.

CARTER: Really exciting.

MCDOWELL: Bless you both. And Happy holidays. A Happy Thanksgiving to both of you. Caroline and Isabel Bercaw, take care and please come back.

C. BERCAW: Thank you so much for having us.

MCDOWELL: Absolutely. Still ahead, head quarter headache, Amazon facing new pushback over the planned New York offices, even a parody on "SNL". We'll tell you more, next hour, MORNINGS WITH MARIA.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

END
