urn:contentItem:5GM0-TF31-F190-V4H0-00000-00Risk & Reward for August 3, 20152015-08-03T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:03ZLexisNexisRisk & Reward for August 3, 2015

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, AFTER THE BELL SHOW HOST: They're not easy. All right. Well, it's good to be back.

MELISSA FRANCIS, AFTER THE BELL CO-HOST: It is. I missed you. We're glad you're back.

ASMAN: Thank you for letting me into your host. Thank you very much. It's very kind of you.

FRANCIS: Don't go away again.

ASMAN: I won't. Never again.

FRANCIS: Go ahead Risk & Reward.

ASMAN: That does it for us. Deirdre Bolton is here to take you through the next hour of Risk & Reward.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: Thank you very much.

ASMAN: She will give you the whole...

FRANCIS: Yes.

BOLTON: Melissa and David. This hour, Twitter at a record low. We're going to give you the takeover odds. Microsoft investing $100 million in Uber. Why that spells trouble for Google.

And republican presidential candidate Jim Gilmore is the 17th to announce. He's going to be joining me here to tell us why he is number one. Risk & Reward starts now.

Hackers can go after airplanes, cars, government data, corporate e-mail like Sony. Now, Chinese hackers may have hit the University of Connecticut exposing thousands of student's social security and credit card details. Fortalice CEO former White House CIO, Theresa Payton is with me now. Theresa, I want to know, of course, how this happen, but why? Why the University of Connecticut? Why students?

THERESA PAYTON, FORTALICE CEO: Well, here is the thing. The hackers have realized, hey, where is the next treasure trove that I can go after that might be a little easier to break into than the banks and some of the other companies and industries that have been hit hard. And they think, ah, colleges and universities.

I can steal a research and I can steal everything about a student not just their major, but if they've applied for financial aid, they have their parent's information, the student's information. All of the financial data that they need to not only masquerade as the student, potentially also as their parents who are on these forms.

It sounds like they've been in there almost two years as well. So, who knows how much information the bad guys got away with this time?

BOLTON: OK. Now, the hack was discovered in March but probably happened back in September 2013. So, intruders had lot of opportunities to use data that they stole. Why did it take so long to pinpoint?

PAYTON: Well, what's happening with the hackers they've changed tactics. They're not as nosy as they used to be when they break-in and they don't try and run out the door with all of the crown jewels at the same time. They watch how the systems work, they watch how the system security works, and then they will find different ways to try and sneak around that.

They may have used credentials of legitimate employees at the university or legitimate vendor credentials. And they may have used that to actually slip the data out the door -- just quietly and under sort of the guys of legitimate credentials.

We don't know because that investigation is still ongoing. You know, the other piece, too, is they may never be able to trust this network again. The fact that they were in this long they can hide themselves in files, in system files, the operating system, and they can actually be there and come back time and time again. So, it's going to be very difficult to get the bad guys out of this network.

BOLTON: OK. Now, how do we know, Theresa, that it's China?

PAYTON: We don't really know for sure until the investigation concludes. And I always caution organizations when they say it's (AUDIO GAP) or Russia or they pick a country to (AUDIO GAP). Look, I can send traffic from any country in the world that I want to so that you think the traffic is originating in that country.

A lots of hackers know that China is in the forefront of discussions and so they may be sending their traffic from China. Until the forensics continues and they look at different things like what was the native language of the hackers? What types of tools and techniques did they use because each one in the cyber syndicates kind of has their own fingerprint method, if you will. And that really has not happened yet. And until it does we don't know for sure that it was China.

BOLTON: So, do you think we're just going to see more and more of these kinds of attacks?

PAYTON: Absolutely. I think what every organization needs to realize -- if you are connected to the Internet and you have one piece of data that's of value to hackers. They will find a way to monetize it or use you as a disguise to hack somebody else.

These hacks are going to continue until we start taking matters into our own hands. For starters, these kids who are just starting their lives this pivotal moment they have got to not just trust on free credit reporting, they have to freeze their credits.

From a university standpoint, they want to be open minds open and trusting. They have to go back and look at what's valuable information here and start locking that off whether it's from vendors looking at user access controls. They need to start locking up this data and every organization should take a lesson from today and ask some critical questions of themselves, how safe is our data and who might be after it?

BOLTON: And we know that the engineering school helped you to discover it. So, I guess more schools as well will be tapping in-house resources. Theresa Payton, thank you as always. Fortalice CEO, former White House CIO.

Well, staying on the scene, less a week after the White House said, it would not retaliate against China for hacking. President Obama plotting to take action. This is according to The New York Times.

Retired Lieutenant Colonel Bill Cowan with me now. So, Colonel, why this reversal of opinion and of action?

BILL COWAN, FOX NEWS MILITARY ANALYST: Probably a lot of pressure from him, Deirdre. About the fact that 22 million of people's information private data got hacked including my own as a guy who used to have a security clearance. So, I think the White House -- a lot of pressure from Congress, pressure from the public, the White House is deciding they have to do something.

At this point, they're thinking about doing something. They haven't quite said they will do anything.

BOLTON: So, Colonel, China has maintained -- it did nothing. I mean, they've actually come out with a statement saying, "It was not us." So, what can the Obama administration really do? Will there will be a symbolic response? Or will there be something a little bit more aggressive?

COWAN: No. I think it will be symbolic and vast because they don't want to get in some kind of tit for tat. A spot with the Chinese who have all - - as much leverage over us certainly as we do over them in the financial sector, the business sector. So, my guess is, excuse my term here, but maybe we'll bitch slap them a little bit but we may not do much more than that.

But the real thing, Deirdre, I believe is, when something like this happens and the White House tried to pretend that China didn't do it -- I think they knew almost from the outset that it was China. When something like this happens the only way we counter these kinds of things is fast, aggressive, unquestionable response of the same nature of what they did to us.

BOLTON: So, I hear what you're saying. In other words, we have to make it uncomfortable for anyone attacking us. So, at least they think twice about doing it again.

COWAN: That's exactly right. And you know what, as your previous guest was just saying, it's the Chinese, the Russians, the Iranians, it might be some kid in the basement in Toronto who's learned how to make cyber-attack on us. But if we're not able to stand up decisively and firmly almost immediately upon knowing who it was and do something to them, they are going to continue to do this to us forever.

BOLTON: Colonel, we're so glad you're with us. Bill Cowan joining us there. Retiring -- retired rather, lieutenant colonel there with us on this very latest with cyber security.

Well, speaking of tech but from a different aspect, Microsoft recent investment part of why Uber has a valuation of more than $50 billion.

Doug MacMillan is here. He broke the story for The Wall Street Journal. So, Doug, Microsoft and Uber, are they new BFF?

DOUG MACMILLAN, WALL STREET JOURNAL REPORTER: Maybe not BFF as much as they are business partners. You know, Uber has been pushing to build its own technology and its own maps. And we've heard as part of the latest financing round, they disclosed that they've been looking for big technology partners to help them do that.

Now, Microsoft is really not known as the cutting edge of maps but they are one of the few large technology companies that does have assets and expertise and engineers who are working on maps specifically in Bing mapping division.

Now, last month or actually in June, Uber announces it's acquiring some of those Bing assets. But apparently, Microsoft and Uber have also worked out an arrangement where Microsoft is going to invest in Uber. So, we don't know if they're going to work together going forward but they're now definitely partners with Microsoft owning a very, you know, a hard to come by stake in Uber.

BOLTON: OK. Hard to come by a stake in Uber. You said a few things in there. I just want to know looking at it from Microsoft's angle, does it somehow legitimize or show that Microsoft is in a current field especially -- I don't know, I'm just thinking the Windows 10 upgrade or using yet, had to be free because no one would pay for it. So, does this bring Microsoft back towards cutting edge companies?

MACMILLAN: I wouldn't go that far. But it definitely calls to mind, in earlier Microsoft investment -- the former CEO of Microsoft, Steve Ballmer, invested in Facebook when that company was only at a $15 billion valuation. That investment turned out to be very lucrative for Microsoft.

But with that stake, now being work something like $2.5 billion on its own. So, perhaps Microsoft by investing in Uber could potentially have a good financials when fallen also for its current Satya Nadella can make him kind of look smart and look like he's connected to kind of one of the cutting edge companies here in Silicon Valley.

BOLTON: And this also challenges Uber, right? Because we know that Uber made an initial investment in Uber back in the day. But now Google has also moving towards its own self- driving a cars, so it just seems like Uber has to find another big tech partners that can write big checks.

MACMILLAN: Yes. This is one of the most interesting stories about Uber. As one of its earliest investors and closest partners is now also increasingly looking like a competitor. So, with Uber trying to distance itself more from Google, there is definitely an element of, you know, is Uber taking money from Microsoft because of this "enemy of my enemy is my friend" principle. We don't know the story of that but definitely it's a juicy story line.

BOLTON: All right. Well, diplomacy important even among tech companies. Doug MacMillan, thank you so much. Great scoop for The Wall Street Journal. We want to bring you up-to-date with some breaking news

Debt ravage of Puerto Rico officially in default. Moody is saying, you paid $628,000 but that is a fraction of the 58 million that was due, that is the default in our book. So, Moody's is in fact saying that Puerto Rico has defaulted and you do have of course, Puerto Rican officials saying, we don't want to default, we do not want a debt spiral to start.

We will bring you up-to-date with the very latest headlines and reaction.

In the meantime, tech billionaire Elon Musk warning against using robots in the military. But our next guest says he is making a big mistake. We'll tell you why.

Plus, the first GOP presidential debate is on Thursday. One of the candidates is joining us tonight with his plan for America. Stay tuned.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Here are some of the stories we are following for you at this hour. Twitter shares touching a record low as the company went public. You'll recall November 2014, but shares plunged today and they are down below $30 a share for the first time in more than a year. Some say, this makes it a takeover target.

President Obama unveiling a major climate change plan. It aimed at large reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from the nation's coal burning power plants. The EPA is estimating the plan would cost around $8.5 billion.

Vice President Joe Biden has begun to actively explore a possible presidential campaign. The New York Times columnist reporting that Biden had been holding meetings such as his residents about jumping in to challenge Mrs. Clinton in Iowa and New Hampshire. He could pose the biggest threat of any democrat as the front runner to Hillary Clinton.

U.S. oil worth noting here settling at 45.17 a barrel, the lowest in more than four months. Continuing a trend of a reduction of about 50 percent since the fall.

Well, the future of modern warfare is like any other industry, technology will play a big role. Last week, where than 1,000 researchers including Elon Musk and Stephen Hawking signed a letter to the U.N. asking for a ban on the development and use of autonomous weapons or killer robots.

My next guest says they will actually save lives. The author of "Ghost Fleet," P.W. Singer with me now. So, P.W., thanks so much for joining us. Why do you disagree with those who signed the letter, those are some of our best and brightest minds?

P.W. SINGER, "GHOST FLEET" AUTHOR: I don't disagree with this sentiment that they want it cause positive change in the world. I think what I disagree with is the idea of how effective this effort is going to be. The book that we did documents right now at least 21 different cases of working on this kind of weaponry in the U.S. in China, et cetera.

And the reason the militaries are working on this is not because they think it's cool, it's not because of, you know, some kind of terminator vision. Because they think it's going to be useful. And so, if this effort is going to win out, this letter writing campaign it's going to have to overcome the idea of use.

The other thing to mention here is of course, it's not just the military that's working on robotics and autonomy, its private business. Its companies like Google and Amazon and the like. And so, if it's playing out in the civilian sector it's going to happen, it's going to move over in the war too.

BOLTON: OK. But how can we estimate or how can we make it so that only the right armies -- this sound like a crazy question -- are building this and not the wrong ones? I mean, who's the judge?

SINGER: Well, I think you've just put your finger on the problem. Every single technology in history has been used for both good and bad whether it's a stone or whether it's a drone. With drone we've seen everything from the U.S. military to ISIS fly to them.

I think what makes these technologies so challenging is that they have very low barriers to entry right now. And so, for looking at a future conflict be it a small war or a big war with the China or Russia, all the different players are going to have this technology. And that's a very big difference for the U.S. that weak for in Ghost Fleet. Is what does it mean to go on to a war where you're not a generation the head of the other side in technology.

BOLTON: And as for when we see this kind technology in the battlefield? When is it?

SINGER: Well, we're already seeing robotics in the battlefield right now. You know, for example, in the war against the ISIS everyone from the U.S. military to the Syrian military to ISIS itself have flown drones. I think if you're looking forward to the 2020s period, you're going to see technology that's more and more autonomous.

And by that, I mean, not just the cars that we drive on highways or Amazon delivery drones but also the drones that are out there in the battlefield. And, you know, for example, the U.S. Navy has already tested out a drone that took off and landed from an aircraft carrier on its own. The toughest human pilot task. That of course is going to move into a future war.

Same thing, China has three different long range strike programs that are droned, that are not unmanned. If we were to fight them they would be using this kind of technologies. So, the bottom line here is that, if there was a World War, which we explore in this book, it would be one where you'd see a mix of man and machine.

And of course, it's not just robotics systems in and of themselves. It's that the manned systems will become more robotic. A lot like how we have cars right now that can parallel park themselves.

The U.S. Navy is building a new warship...

BOLTON: Right.

SINGER: ... that it has about one-tenth the size of the crew in the past. Because the war ship is so highly robotics.

BOLTON: P.W., glad to have you with us. Thank you for sharing your thoughts. Great book. P.W. Singer joining us there, he is the author of "Ghost Fleet."

Well, stock you saw in the red today. We're going to look at the correlation between earnings and performance. SO, you had 65 companies in the NASDAQ, 100 reporting. Stocks swinging up or down at an average of more 5 percent immediately after reporting results.

All in the last three weeks, the highest volatility, if you like, on that front since 2012.

Bob Rice is here. Managing partner at Tangent Capital, author of "The Alternative Answer." Bob, one minute on the clock. Please explain correlate.

BOB RICE, TANGENT CAPITAL MANAGING PARTNER: So, correlation is a very simple but very important concept. You know, just free first to how closely a given stocks movement track the movement of the larger index.

And so, when you're in the period of high correlation, you can really think of it like a flock of birds. One bird turns a little bit they all turn a little bit. One turns dramatically they all turn dramatically. The opposite of that is when all stocks have different kinds they are in the early minds and they act as you see here like a herd of cats instead.

So, that's a low correlation environment. And the reason this is important is we seem to be transitioning from a high correlation to a low correlation right now, and that matters. Because over the last few years, frankly, it hasn't made that much difference exactly which stocks you own because they all acted alike. They were highly correlated.

We're moving now to a different period, (inaudible) correlation, you're going to have to be a lot more careful about what's exactly in your portfolio.

BOLTON: All right. With 10 seconds to go, leave bulls and bears aside, we're going to do cats and birds here. But, Bob, most importantly, why is this happening now?

RICE: Well, I think it's because you're seeing peeling back of quantitative easing than we were very cheap flooded with easy money, all boats were...

BOLTON: For nine years.

RICE: Yes. We're coming up with that tie. Now, it's starting to be different. And you can see it very clearly in what you were saying in the intro there. Up until very recently it didn't really matter whether stock beat its earnings estimate or disappointed. It was still in the flock of birds. It behaves like the rest of the flock. All of a sudden it matters dramatically. If you beat your earnings estimates you do way better than the average. If you disappoint you do way worse. And that's what is important for investors to start paying attention too.

To see that the investor can do that.

BOLTON: The number one thing an inventor can do then going into this environment. Diversification I imagine.

RICE: Well, yes. But over diversification because now matters exactly which ones you're in. And so, you want to be in more concentrated higher conviction portfolios and not so much super broad based ETFs and indexes.

BOLTON: Bob Rice, we thank you as always. Bob Rice joining us there, managing partner at Tangent Capital, also the author of "The Alternative Answer."

Well, speaking of volatility, the Greek stock market reopened for the first time in five weeks. It was a blood bath dropping more than 20 percent, just a few minutes into the open, banking stocks hit the worst.

With us now to discuss this kind of volatility, Jason Rosiak. He is senior managing director at Pacific Asset Management. Jason, thanks for coming in.

JASON ROSIAK, PACIFIC ASSET MANAGEMENT SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR: Thank you very much.

BOLTON: So, we're just hearing from Bob Rice about correlation, perhaps this breaks lots of volatility whether it's Greece, whether it's China, whether it's Iran, there are certainly a lot of hot spots in the world. What are you doing with your money?

ROSIAK: Right now it's being at the core for a bottom's up firm. So, one of the things that we're looking at is corporate credit and the focus is on fundamentals and coverage. And so, with Greece right now, for instance, the stock market was down by 16 percent today, challenging but that's just an underlying risk associated with what's going on there in the volatility.

BOLTON: So, not the average person can as of this moment go out and buy a Greek debt? But it sounds like you're saying for professional investors this is an opportunity?

ROSIAK: It's not for Greek debt but for corporate debt in the U.S. side. So, what we do is we focus on bank loans. And bank loans are floating arrangements that usually general names that PetSmart, Chuck E. Cheese, those types of names that are U.S.-based focused yield anywhere between 3 to 6 percent. The floating rates don't have to worry about duration risk. And it's a noble...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: So, let's say the Fed moves in either September or December as fed for the future are indicating. What does this mean?

ROSIAK: So, for this asset class which is nice, is not -- it doesn't have duration. So, therefore, it's dependent on the corporate underlying how they react and how they fundamentally performed. So, unlike other asset classes that generally speaking, people use in inflationary or high rising rates environment whether it be you're sitting in tips or you're sit in real estate or commodities, there is a lot of volatility there.

BOLTON: OK.

ROSIAK: In the taper tension you had commodities go down by about 4 percent, and TIPS go down by 7 percent, or as bank loans.

BOLTON: And TIPS, Inflation Protective Securities.

ROSIAK: Correct.

BOLTON: For those who do not follow as closely as you do. The best idea you've heard of in the past few weeks?

ROSIAK: Best idea, we still like corporate credit. We like triple B investment-grade credit fairly these are amounts of spread involved there. And it's better than owning interest-rate sensitive or commodities sensitive type of assets.

BOLTON: All right. Jason, come back. We want to continue the conversation another time. Jason Rosiak joining me there. Senior managing director at Pacific Asset Management.

When we come back, Uber may be recruiting your grandparents. We are not joking. Older drivers may be safer drivers. First though, former Governor Jim Gilmore may have announced the 17th kisses. He's going to end up as number one. He is my guest, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: There are 17 republican candidates running for president in 2016. With us now the very latest contender, former Virginia Governor, Jim Gilmore with us from D.C.

Governor, glad to have you with us.

JIM GILMORE, FORMER VIRGINIA GOVERNOR: Thank you, Deirdre.

BOLTON: You are entering a crowded GOP field. What do you hope to gain and why now?

GILMORE: Well, I hope to gain the ability to turn the country around from the decline that it's in, wherein a decline in our national security in our safety of Americans and the American interests. We're in a decline in the economy. The economy has never really recovered from the recession. We're really not doing well enough.

And I think I have the credentials in order to being turn this around. All my life I have fought on behalf of my state in my country. I'm a United States army veteran. I was the chairman of the National Commission on Terrorism for the United States. I was the governor during the 9/11 attack.

I've been the governor of a state and band I stood had to deal with budgets and create jobs and do things. So, I've always been in a position I think to really help this. And right now I see a decline in America that I think I can reverse.

BOLTON: So, Governor, I want to pick up on exactly what you just said, this background as an army intelligence officer, we talked about cyber on this program every single day. What is the number one thing that could be changed right now to better protect America? Does it need to hire more engineers? What does the budget need to look like? How can we improve cyber security of our businesses and our citizens right now?

GILMORE: Well, we're going to have to recognize with presidential leadership exactly the nature of the society we live in. When I was the governor I was known as the technology governor because I've really pushed forward on all of our policies and programs and also cyber issues.

We have to recognize that opposition people really try to and do us right now. Look at the Chinese situation. They've gone in now and invaded our records with people who have security clearances and there's been an absolutely no repercussions.

This is an example once again, of the decline of the United States because of the Obama-Clinton foreign policy. We need to make it that America is back. The best way to do that is to remove the sequester limits from our defense department to get full or move forward once again in the restoration of American strength.

And of course, that's going to require of the American economy.

BOLTON: So, to spend more on defense. If you could change one thing, let's say, you're elected, what would you do the first order of business?

GILMORE: The first order of business is to restore the American economy. Right now we are discouraging business. You heard Hillary Clinton actually talk about trying to attack business in this country and income equality and all those kinds of warm ball of marches kind of ideas.

What you have to do is to make a renewal once again of the free enterprise system in this country. And that means that we have to actually to put in policies that don't discourage investment but restoring investment in this country. Investment means more productivity. More productivity means more jobs. And more jobs means higher wages.

And we're not going to be able to have a real national security until we restore the American economy to give a better quality of life of the American people and a stronger economy to protect ourselves in this dangerous world.

BOLTON: Governor, you used to be chairman as well of the Republican National party, the republican National Committee. I want to ask you what do you make of Donald Trump? There are so many pundits, so many republicans who keep waiting for his campaign to run out of steam but it's not. Is he what the American public wants?

GILMORE: I think that he's struck a nerve, a resentment, and anger in among the American people. I thought about it a lot. I don't have any real interest in that. What I have an interest in is actually making the country better and responding to this anger and to this resentment with genuine positive programs.

And that's what why I've talked to you about here today. If we put forward a program that gives a tax cut to working Americans that combines all business activity and charges at 15 percent tax rate, if we eliminate the debt tax, our economists have told us that what that will do is get the economy moving again. Get us up to growth over 4 percent, do something that really create some dynamic excitement in this economy.

That's the kind of anger and resentment because people know that the people in Washington are not doing anything to move the country forward. That's why I think I'm qualified to do. That's what I want to achieve. I want to reverse this decline from the Obama-Clinton policy, that's why I've entered the presidential race.

BOLTON: All right. Governor, we're glad to have you with us. Thank you for the time. Former Virginia Governor and 2016 presidential candidate, Jim Gilmore.

Well, will Trump maintain his number one spot? Tune in right after this show at 6 p.m. Eastern Time sharp. Charles Payne has Fox's exclusive latest poll numbers.

When we come back, though Twitter getting crushed, some say it is a live takeover target. We're going to give you a short list of would-be buyers.

But first, Uber is announcing a partnership with the AARP to recruit older drivers. We'll talk about the fact whether it a PR sons or a real business initiative.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Twitter shares closed at the all-time low. Jack Hidary is here. He is the former CEO of Dice.com. Ari Zaldan is here as well. The CEO of Quantum Networks. Welcome to you both.

JACK HIDARY, FORMER DICE.COM CEO: Great to see you.

BOLTON: Great to see you. So, is Twitter in play? Aye (ph) or nay?

HIDARY: Twitter is in trouble.

BOLTON: OK.

HIDARY: Twitter does not know where it's going. It's headless, stateless, does not have a leader right now, there's no captain of the ship. And also it doesn't know what it's doing because it is a 300 million monthly active users has not grown effectively in two years.

BOLTON: And to you point, there is no CEO, I mean, jack Dorsey is there, one of the original founders but he had said...

HIDARY: But he's also the CEO of Square. Yes.

BOLTON: Yes. I mean, it's clear that he is a part-time or transitional. So, $30 actually per share is a number that I saw a lot of analysts come up with it and say, you know what, this starts to look cheap enough for someone to buy. What is your take?

ARI ZOLDAN, QUANTUM NETWORKS CEO: Right. Yes. I think $30 is a great buy. I don't think it's cheap but I think it's a good buy. And I think to push back a little bit, they will get a CEO and I think they're get a really good CEO. The question is when. But you're right. Right now it's sort of in between times. So, I think there's a lot of questions out on the street.

HIDARY: But when the CEO comes the question is, what's their strategy, right? What kind of practice is it? Why is it not growing even though every show, including this one, talks Twitter all the time.

BOLTON: Well, I think it's great for journalist and I love it. I'm an addict. I say that openly, but it's true that if you're not in media and you're not reading I don't know why you would do if you're not in this field.

HIDARY: SO, WhatsApp is growing, Snapchat is growing by leaps and bounds. Yet, twitter just remains flat. So, there is a real crisis in terms of how do you grow this. You can't grow. You're not going to grow revenues and profit either.

BOLTON: OK. And of course, you know, as you say, Facebook hot on the heels with its own app. Uber is partnering with AARP. I don't know if you saw that Simpsons clip there. But is this idea the older drivers are safer drivers? PR, real business strategy, what do you think?

ZOLDAN: No, real business. It's real and I think it's great. You know, it's not cutie. I think it's very real. You have a million Uber rides per day, a 160,000 drivers out there on behalf of Uber. And you have a demographic that's older, a lot of them are unemployed but they're also great drivers. So, it's a perfect strategic fit.

BOLTON: Jack, over there.

ZOLDAN: This is part of a larger trend which is, people is going to be driving their own cars less and less. This is going to be major calamity in terms of the car. Rental companies in terms of giving car sales.

BOLTON: Well, Uber even started that leasing arm. Did you see that?

HIDARY: That's right.

BOLTON: So, they probably are even anticipating exactly what you're saying.

HIDARY: Yes. So, they need more drivers. They're looking for pools and demographic. The drivers will agree, this is going to be a great demographic for them to grow into. They're going to have to get two to three million rides per day. They need more drivers to get there.

BOLTON: All right. Speaking of more driving. At least in New York City that means less walking which makes me think of the maybe shaking up its fitness requirements saying, you know what, if you're strong you can be a little heavier, if you can still do the work you're supposed to do basically you don't care.

HIDARY: Well, you know, this is a fundamental shift from one or twice a year checking in a physical, right? That's the way we've always thought about health and health checking. We go for the physical, annual physical in a nay it's been twice a year to now continuous modeling.

So, this is a Fitbit tracker right here. Other people use the Apple watch, of course. The navy is choosing the Fitbit tracker right now to give it to their sailors and say, hey, 24/7, let's actually get a general bigger picture sense of how you're doing health wise and that of course connect with the phone which gives you all those metrics and data. That's what they're looking for, the overall messaging of the data not just once a year physicals.

ZOLDAN: Yes. I happen to be but I think this stuff is great. And it's also an accessory. I think it has part of a lifestyle obviously. And look, you know, I'm not a good case study for you're an authorize (ph) than I am. But I think I agree checking in once or twice I don't it's going to do. I think this technology is great but I think an overall lifestyle change for the navy I think would be a good move.

BOLTON: All right. Here hear. There we go. Hold those thought. We're going to take a quick break. We'll be right back with Jack and Ari. Of course, we just want to let you know, there is some breaking news here on GM ignition switch death and injuries now totaling 398 faulty ignition switches responsible for at least 124 deaths, 274 injuries.

This is a according to a fund set up to compensate victims. The fund just finished processing these papers. More than 4,000 claims it had received by the January 1st deadline. Those numbers just being released now.

When we come back, actress Jessica Alba's sunscreen customers are getting burnt. What her response means for her clients and her competitors.

First stuff, an app that makes your next set of eyeglasses much easier to get. We will introduce you to the CEO who has seen the future in 2020.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: More than 75 percent of adults in the U.S. use some form of vision correction. Opternative is trying to make getting contacts or glasses easier, users' take an online exam. They receive a prescription within 24 hours off from their homes.

Co-founder and CEO Aaron Dallek is with me now. So, Aaron, do people get equally accurate results as going to an eye doctor's office?

AARON DALLEK, OPTERNATIVE CO-FOUNDER & CEO: Yes. They do. Opternative is clinically proven to be statistically equivalent to the traditional refractive eye exam done in the doctor's office.

BOLTON: OK. Now, you're located in 27 states and counting. What was that process like to get approved in each state?

DALLEK: So, we worked with our lawyers and we've registered with the FDA. And we've made sure that we follow all the regulations in all of the states and we've hired ophthalmologists licensed in all of these states to make it so that we can practice in these states.

BOLTON: All right. Warby Parker is a big online eyeglass brand. It's kind of like Tom shoes but for glasses. Do you see that company as competition?

DALLEK: Warby Parker is a great online retailer and one of many that we hope to partner with in helping your customers and helping our customers get glasses using our test.

BOLTON: OK. So, you see them more as a complementary service versus being an outright competitor. I do know that your service requires computer and a Smartphone. So, you have plans to target under serve or impoverished areas, maybe people in places that don't have tablets that are ready?

DALLEK: Yes. Absolutely. We're looking to make our technology available to as many people as possible make it available so proctors can help people who can't go through the exam on their own, help people in other countries, help people in the U.S. who under served. So, it's very important part of our business.

BOLTON: All right. Now as far as protecting the data we know medical information among the most personal, how high on your list is privacy?

DALLEK: Security is a top priority. We are officially HIPA compliant and we use top level enterprise security to insure all of our patient data is secure and encrypted at every level.

BOLTON: Aaron, we're glad to have with us. Thanks for joining us. Aaron Dallek, he is the Opternative co-founder and CEO.

When we come back, Jessica Alba is feeling the heat. Some of her sunscreens, some customer say, they're getting burned. Spells opportunity for competing brand. And the city of brotherly love apparently not so love being to the treatment of a hitchhiking robot. We will give you the details.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Jessica Alba on its company getting burned for its sunscreen. Customers taking to social media claiming that the ecofriendly cream doesn't work. Jack Hidary back with me now as of Ari Zoldan. So, are social media sites Twitter, Instagram, anything else just becoming the new yelp, the new consumer reports?

HIDARY: You know, in this age of Internet transparency is number one. You have to be transparent. You could be led by a superstar, you could be led a great show, it doesn't matter. You need to be super transparent with your customer base.

BOLTON: We're looking at these kids who are sunburned.

HIDARY: Oh, my, God.

BOLTON: And I mean, even more...

HIDARY: Yes.

BOLTON: ... sort of when it's a child you think like, ah.

HIDARY: The hospitality as you know as well from trip adviser, right. You get two or three bad reviews in trip advisory, your hotel, your airlines, your resort could be done for it. And so, many industries now are very responsive because of social media and because of side trip advisor, that's now coming to the consumer price as well.

BOLTON: But I hear what you're saying she named the company honest, so she set a higher bar for her.

HIDARY: Exactly. And there's good present for that. Look at honesty very successful but they had to go against Snapple, a much bigger company using the transparency. The same thing with Canbar (ph). Canbar is so successful today in part because of its transparent packaging literally saying we will tell you what's inside.

BOLTON: Yes.

HIDARY: The other guys -- exactly. The other guys are concealing what's inside. So, there is a lot of good precedent for going with honest concept but then you have to live up to it.

BOLTON: Ari, what is your take?

ZOLDAN: And you have to be -- right. And you have to be honest about it.

HIDARY: Yes.

ZOLDAN: Yes, I agree with Jack. I think today the fact that every one that has an Internet connection means everyone has a voice for every products and every service that they buy. So, you know, they become either an advocate or proponent, you know, for the actual product.

BOLTON: So, if you're with crisis management for the Honest company, what would you tell her right now?

ZOLDAN: I think she has to be forward. She has to honest about it just like come after whether she was in actually -- if she was intimately involved with the process or not. And I think she has to be very outspoken about it. And I think that the media especially the public I think they appreciate that that.

HIDARY: Yes, I agree. They maybe and she was in the zinc component right now.

BOLTON: Right.

HIDARY: So, if you look at other kinds of, you know, honest oriented suntan lotions they have a higher zinc component. It could be they lower the zinc component that's why you're seeing those.

BOLTON: That's what I've read.

HIDARY: Red burns. So, they have to get to the bottom and then come forward and share that and engage to the community because if not, you have situations like Market Basket. This is $4-billion supermarket chain and they fire the CEO, they technically could fire the CEO, the customers, the vendors, the entire chain shut down for 30 days to protest and say, bring back that CEO, we want them.

BOLTON: All right. Strong, speaking of engagement, engaging the users. You've write in the drone.

HIDARY: We did.

BOLTON: Speaking of engaging, aircraft is swerving to avoid a drone in South Jersey. Because we know that all of the anti-drone people are going to say, see, this is why you can't have drones, this is why you can't move for all of this.

HIDARY: Yes.

BOLTON: But, in essence it is actually a fair point. I mean, the pilot of a smaller aircraft basically almost had an accident with the drone.

HIDARY: Yes. You know, we have to deal with drones. Drones are reality.

BOLTON: They're here.

HIDARY: Drones are very useful. This happens to be a drone with a camera right here in front could take pictures of real estate could be helpful to farmers, could be helpful to lots of different industry. This is not just for recreational use but actually for industrial use as well.

So, drones are here and they offer a lot of value. The question is, how are we going to regulate them? Right now there is a lot of ambiguity around that. We need to find a way to both protect people's privacy and also have a way to have drone's out there.

BOLTON: But now pretend that they don't exist. I saw an even crazier things which is somebody at the FAA is looking at this possibility...

HIDARY: Yes.

BOLTON: ... drones so that drones it does not -- they can't fly above a certain air space. That to me seems crazier than just establishing the kind of channel.

ZOLDAN: Right. Could you imagine that this is only the first generation like we're just scratching the surface.

HIDARY: That's right.

ZOLDAN: Can you imagine what is this going to look like in three months, in three years, or 30 years, talking about, you know, just thinking about the sophistication of it. So, obviously a regulation is extremely important whether it's in the form of geo fencing of figuring how to protect your area and your air space.

BOLTON: Yes.

ZOLDAN: I think is the big topic of the conversation.

BOLTON: We know Amazon.com obviously lobbying hard...

HIDARY: For prime add.

BOLTON: ... to have a -- yes, just a sky highway.

ZOLDAN: Right. And then you have paparazzi's now using drones as well to go in -- the question is, are you going to have a drone to drawn combat. Are you going to have some drones defending and other drones trying to look at.

BOLTON: A new stage of video games.

HIDARY: Exactly.

BOLTON: Jack Hidary, thank you so much. Ari Zoldan joining me there for a great conversation. Thank you both. We have a quick break to take. When we come back we were on top of it when it broke. Now it is literally broke. Find out how the hitchhiking robot made its way across all kinds of countries and then met its demise in the city of brotherly love.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Here are some of the top stories trending on foxbusiness.com. right now. Kraft recalling 36,000 cases of singles cheese. A few customers complained of choking on the plastic wrapping. It is the second recall for Kraft. In March, more than 240,000 packages of macaroni and cheese was recalled over worry that some boxes contained metal pieces.

From food to autos, July sales strong on track with the industry yearly estimate. If current levels are maintained, sales will hit a 14-year high. Trucks and SUVs the most popular of this month. Ford saw the best July since 2006.

And the CEO that cut his $1 million salary. So, all of his employees could have a minimum wage of $70,000 a year, seem hard times. The company is losing talents. They say the system rewards slackers and provides no incentives for innovation. The CEO is now renting out his house to make ends meet.

For the latest on news and analysis, go to foxbusiness.com.

Well, the Canadian built HitchBOT began its coast to coast trip on the U.S., that was July 17th. It made it all across Canada and Europe. But when it came to Philadelphia, the second leg of the trip beginning in Massachusetts, you can just track how it is there along with other landmarks.

But you can see in the city of Brotherly Love, none at all. The hitchBOT was found destroyed on the side of the road just 300 miles into its U.S. trip.

We are so glad you joined us here on Risk & Reward. We remind you to check at our full web site interviews, bonus content there foxbusiness.com. Charles Payne is next with Making Money. A special poll. He has the result. Keep it right here.

END

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, AFTER THE BELL SHOW HOST: They're not easy. All right. Well, it's good to be back.

MELISSA FRANCIS, AFTER THE BELL CO-HOST: It is. I missed you. We're glad you're back.

ASMAN: Thank you for letting me into your host. Thank you very much. It's very kind of you.

FRANCIS: Don't go away again.

ASMAN: I won't. Never again.

FRANCIS: Go ahead Risk & Reward.

ASMAN: That does it for us. Deirdre Bolton is here to take you through the next hour of Risk & Reward.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: Thank you very much.

ASMAN: She will give you the whole...

FRANCIS: Yes.

BOLTON: Melissa and David. This hour, Twitter at a record low. We're going to give you the takeover odds. Microsoft investing $100 million in Uber. Why that spells trouble for Google.

And republican presidential candidate Jim Gilmore is the 17th to announce. He's going to be joining me here to tell us why he is number one. Risk & Reward starts now.

Hackers can go after airplanes, cars, government data, corporate e-mail like Sony. Now, Chinese hackers may have hit the University of Connecticut exposing thousands of student's social security and credit card details. Fortalice CEO former White House CIO, Theresa Payton is with me now. Theresa, I want to know, of course, how this happen, but why? Why the University of Connecticut? Why students?

THERESA PAYTON, FORTALICE CEO: Well, here is the thing. The hackers have realized, hey, where is the next treasure trove that I can go after that might be a little easier to break into than the banks and some of the other companies and industries that have been hit hard. And they think, ah, colleges and universities.

I can steal a research and I can steal everything about a student not just their major, but if they've applied for financial aid, they have their parent's information, the student's information. All of the financial data that they need to not only masquerade as the student, potentially also as their parents who are on these forms.

It sounds like they've been in there almost two years as well. So, who knows how much information the bad guys got away with this time?

BOLTON: OK. Now, the hack was discovered in March but probably happened back in September 2013. So, intruders had lot of opportunities to use data that they stole. Why did it take so long to pinpoint?

PAYTON: Well, what's happening with the hackers they've changed tactics. They're not as nosy as they used to be when they break-in and they don't try and run out the door with all of the crown jewels at the same time. They watch how the systems work, they watch how the system security works, and then they will find different ways to try and sneak around that.

They may have used credentials of legitimate employees at the university or legitimate vendor credentials. And they may have used that to actually slip the data out the door -- just quietly and under sort of the guys of legitimate credentials.

We don't know because that investigation is still ongoing. You know, the other piece, too, is they may never be able to trust this network again. The fact that they were in this long they can hide themselves in files, in system files, the operating system, and they can actually be there and come back time and time again. So, it's going to be very difficult to get the bad guys out of this network.

BOLTON: OK. Now, how do we know, Theresa, that it's China?

PAYTON: We don't really know for sure until the investigation concludes. And I always caution organizations when they say it's (AUDIO GAP) or Russia or they pick a country to (AUDIO GAP). Look, I can send traffic from any country in the world that I want to so that you think the traffic is originating in that country.

A lots of hackers know that China is in the forefront of discussions and so they may be sending their traffic from China. Until the forensics continues and they look at different things like what was the native language of the hackers? What types of tools and techniques did they use because each one in the cyber syndicates kind of has their own fingerprint method, if you will. And that really has not happened yet. And until it does we don't know for sure that it was China.

BOLTON: So, do you think we're just going to see more and more of these kinds of attacks?

PAYTON: Absolutely. I think what every organization needs to realize -- if you are connected to the Internet and you have one piece of data that's of value to hackers. They will find a way to monetize it or use you as a disguise to hack somebody else.

These hacks are going to continue until we start taking matters into our own hands. For starters, these kids who are just starting their lives this pivotal moment they have got to not just trust on free credit reporting, they have to freeze their credits.

From a university standpoint, they want to be open minds open and trusting. They have to go back and look at what's valuable information here and start locking that off whether it's from vendors looking at user access controls. They need to start locking up this data and every organization should take a lesson from today and ask some critical questions of themselves, how safe is our data and who might be after it?

BOLTON: And we know that the engineering school helped you to discover it. So, I guess more schools as well will be tapping in-house resources. Theresa Payton, thank you as always. Fortalice CEO, former White House CIO.

Well, staying on the scene, less a week after the White House said, it would not retaliate against China for hacking. President Obama plotting to take action. This is according to The New York Times.

Retired Lieutenant Colonel Bill Cowan with me now. So, Colonel, why this reversal of opinion and of action?

BILL COWAN, FOX NEWS MILITARY ANALYST: Probably a lot of pressure from him, Deirdre. About the fact that 22 million of people's information private data got hacked including my own as a guy who used to have a security clearance. So, I think the White House -- a lot of pressure from Congress, pressure from the public, the White House is deciding they have to do something.

At this point, they're thinking about doing something. They haven't quite said they will do anything.

BOLTON: So, Colonel, China has maintained -- it did nothing. I mean, they've actually come out with a statement saying, "It was not us." So, what can the Obama administration really do? Will there will be a symbolic response? Or will there be something a little bit more aggressive?

COWAN: No. I think it will be symbolic and vast because they don't want to get in some kind of tit for tat. A spot with the Chinese who have all - - as much leverage over us certainly as we do over them in the financial sector, the business sector. So, my guess is, excuse my term here, but maybe we'll bitch slap them a little bit but we may not do much more than that.

But the real thing, Deirdre, I believe is, when something like this happens and the White House tried to pretend that China didn't do it -- I think they knew almost from the outset that it was China. When something like this happens the only way we counter these kinds of things is fast, aggressive, unquestionable response of the same nature of what they did to us.

BOLTON: So, I hear what you're saying. In other words, we have to make it uncomfortable for anyone attacking us. So, at least they think twice about doing it again.

COWAN: That's exactly right. And you know what, as your previous guest was just saying, it's the Chinese, the Russians, the Iranians, it might be some kid in the basement in Toronto who's learned how to make cyber-attack on us. But if we're not able to stand up decisively and firmly almost immediately upon knowing who it was and do something to them, they are going to continue to do this to us forever.

BOLTON: Colonel, we're so glad you're with us. Bill Cowan joining us there. Retiring -- retired rather, lieutenant colonel there with us on this very latest with cyber security.

Well, speaking of tech but from a different aspect, Microsoft recent investment part of why Uber has a valuation of more than $50 billion.

Doug MacMillan is here. He broke the story for The Wall Street Journal. So, Doug, Microsoft and Uber, are they new BFF?

DOUG MACMILLAN, WALL STREET JOURNAL REPORTER: Maybe not BFF as much as they are business partners. You know, Uber has been pushing to build its own technology and its own maps. And we've heard as part of the latest financing round, they disclosed that they've been looking for big technology partners to help them do that.

Now, Microsoft is really not known as the cutting edge of maps but they are one of the few large technology companies that does have assets and expertise and engineers who are working on maps specifically in Bing mapping division.

Now, last month or actually in June, Uber announces it's acquiring some of those Bing assets. But apparently, Microsoft and Uber have also worked out an arrangement where Microsoft is going to invest in Uber. So, we don't know if they're going to work together going forward but they're now definitely partners with Microsoft owning a very, you know, a hard to come by stake in Uber.

BOLTON: OK. Hard to come by a stake in Uber. You said a few things in there. I just want to know looking at it from Microsoft's angle, does it somehow legitimize or show that Microsoft is in a current field especially -- I don't know, I'm just thinking the Windows 10 upgrade or using yet, had to be free because no one would pay for it. So, does this bring Microsoft back towards cutting edge companies?

BOLTON: Jack Hidary, thank you so much. Ari Zoldan joining me there for a great conversation. Thank you both. We have a quick break to take. When we come back we were on top of it when it broke. Now it is literally broke. Find out how the hitchhiking robot made its way across all kinds of countries and then met its demise in the city of brotherly love.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Here are some of the top stories trending on foxbusiness.com. right now. Kraft recalling 36,000 cases of singles cheese. A few customers complained of choking on the plastic wrapping. It is the second recall for Kraft. In March, more than 240,000 packages of macaroni and cheese was recalled over worry that some boxes contained metal pieces.

From food to autos, July sales strong on track with the industry yearly estimate. If current levels are maintained, sales will hit a 14-year high. Trucks and SUVs the most popular of this month. Ford saw the best July since 2006.

And the CEO that cut his $1 million salary. So, all of his employees could have a minimum wage of $70,000 a year, seem hard times. The company is losing talents. They say the system rewards slackers and provides no incentives for innovation. The CEO is now renting out his house to make ends meet.

For the latest on news and analysis, go to foxbusiness.com.

Well, the Canadian built HitchBOT began its coast to coast trip on the U.S., that was July 17th. It made it all across Canada and Europe. But when it came to Philadelphia, the second leg of the trip beginning in Massachusetts, you can just track how it is there along with other landmarks.

But you can see in the city of Brotherly Love, none at all. The hitchBOT was found destroyed on the side of the road just 300 miles into its U.S. trip.

We are so glad you joined us here on Risk & Reward. We remind you to check at our full web site interviews, bonus content there foxbusiness.com. Charles Payne is next with Making Money. A special poll. He has the result. Keep it right here.

END
