MELISSA FRANCIS, AFTER THE BELL SHOW HOST: Nice. Deirdre Bolton gets us out of this. Thank you so much.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: All right. Melissa and David. Thank you so much. We have breaking news to bring you here right away. A senate IRS targeting report has been released. My colleague, Gerri Willis, has been on the story. So, Gerri, what is the latest?

GERRI WILLIS, THE WILLIS REPORT SHOW HOST: So, Deirdre, that's right. We just got report moments ago. And here is what we're finding the big take away, the IRS was delinquent in providing effective control, guidance and direction in the processing of those tax-exempt application for 501-c3 status. That's what we're learning tonight.

And let me tell you, the report describes the culture within the IRS Exempt Organizations Unit. We had no idea how dysfunctional it was. Listen to this. Top management was never aware of five year delays in some of the processing at some of these organizations applications.

In addition to that, people within the unit were improperly trained. They didn't know the kind of material they were looking at, what they were supposed to do, what the law regarding tax-exempt organizations was supposed to be. There was in siding. People were managing folks were halfway across the country, 2,000 miles away, that made it more difficult.

In addition to that, there were people who worked from home four days a week, and it was difficult to get all the information flowing. This made it possible for Lois Lerner because she was very liberal in her outlook on life, it made it possible for her to have her political point of view represented and that's exactly what happened here, according to this report.

They surveyed 1.5 million documents and 32 interviews with IRS employees, staff and others.

BOLTON: So, Gerri, quick question here, I mean, as far as the staff views, what are, for example, republicans saying to this because many feel like, OK, some of the groups that are even right of center were clearly targeted.

WILLIS: That's right. And as you know, the president recently said they were not. But this report says, yes, they were. That the IRS systemically selected tea party groups for targeting, and as I said, Lois Lerner had a big role in this. Orrin Hatch today saying that he found evidence, and he is the chairman of this committee that the administration's political agenda guided the IRS actions; they're calling this gross mismanagement.

When you read the details of how the section was run, Deirdre, I don't think there's a company you cover in technology that is run that way.

BOLTON: OK. And as you said, the president, this could go all the way up to a PR problem for President Obama.

WILLIS: Well, the big question of course has been, has this targeting been directed from the White House? Even though Orrin Hatch concludes that that's what was happening, I saw none of it in the report.

So, we're still waiting to see if that's in fact the case, and that's the big takeaway question so many people have at this time. But let me tell you. Tonight, the Senate Finance Committee painting a picture of complete disarray in this exempt organizations unit.

And I have to tell you, it sounds like they weren't just delinquent and ineffective at controlling and guiding their employees, they didn't know what they were supposed to be doing, it sounds like.

BOLTON: OK. Gerri, we are going to depend on you for updates. In the meantime, thank you very much for bringing us breaking news on that Senate Finance Committee report.

I want to get you to the markets because stocks close higher but essentially went nowhere. If you look at the levels, oil prices slid. We want to get you down to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Lori Rothman is there. Lori, what stood out to you about today's session?

LORI ROTHMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Deirdre. Well, the hundred-point rally we had early fizzling certainly stood out. So, both said and done the Dow is down 10 points to close at 17,540. You hit the nail with that decline in oil prices. So, it looks like four days the down days for the Dow.

The NASDAQ did post gains, about 34 points by the close. Lot of that had to do with finally a turnaround in shares of Apple. Apple shares up 6/10 of a percent, up for the first time in five days, down 14 percent still since April.

We've been talking about the massive amounts of market value. Apple's given up about $100 billion in that time period. Disney was another weight on the Dow, 24 hours later after disappointing earnings report, disappointing revenue to be exact. Apparently, people are cutting the cord, so the cable business is of serious concern.

Disney also warning of mysterious dollar hit, $500 million hit next year to the company because of our strong U.S. dollar. Twitter shares also hit a new low today. A lot of speculation who will be the new CEO and when that person will be appointed. Off almost 3 percent in the regular session. Also Rico reported that Google, an acquisition by Google of Twitter is highly unlikely.

After the bell, we just heard the latest earnings from Tesla, the electric carmaker shares down around. They've been as low as 8 percent in the after- hours which is better than expected report. But here is the problem, Elon Musk, CEO, lowered vehicle sales expectations.

He did promise 55,000 electric vehicles sold this year and he lowered that mark, 50 to 55,000. So, that pretty much sums up the day, Deirdre. I'll send it back over to you.

BOLTON: Lori, thank you so much. I'm going to pick up right where you left off on Tesla. Lori just told you beat on the top and the bottom lines. But this big question, can Elon Musk's company develop and deliver 55,000 cars, you heard her say. It seems like not.

I want to bring in the president and editorial director of TechnoBuffalo, Jon Rettinger. So, Jon, first and foremost, what do you make of the earnings, we'll talk about production in a minute.

JON RETTINGER, TECHNOBUFFALO PRESIDENT AND EDITORIAL DIRECTOR: Sure. So, I think people were disappointed by not hitting the sales number at 55,000 numbers. Numbers has been touted. We're supposed to have the model x this year, the model x kept getting delayed. Now we're hearing we're going to have it start shipping toward the end of the year.

But we heard blames of making sure that they were -- the partners were going to be able to ship on time. And I think we're losing about 10 percent of your total estimated sales is a big hit for the company.

BOLTON: OK. It certainly is indeed. And I mean, what do you make of Tesla, right? Tesla is supposed to be next generation in Siri. We have Elon Musk touting it as bigger, better, faster, stronger, but, I mean, other car companies can meet their production standards?

RETTINGER: Yes. So, Tesla is one of those companies that is being led by a modern-day Steve Jobs. You have this reality extortion field. People love the company but it follows no sense of logic with how the stock goes. I want them to hear a few things that we didn't get from the earnings call.

Tesla has taken over 29,000 orders for the model x but has given no estimation when its designs is going to go live. Cars are going to ship in a few months. We don't even know what they've ordered at this point. I would like to hear more about their power low, their home battery solution. We don't know much about that.

Tesla has been promising autonomous drive called autopilot in the model x. We're hearing very little about that other than it's been delayed. So, there are a lot of question marks for the company, not to mention the specter of their model 3, the affordable BMW 3 killer supposed to hitting sometime in 2017.

BOLTON: OK. And, Jon, I mean, I know you are a fan, you have you driven one, you have come on the show and talked about it. What does it mean for the future? How much does it hurt Tesla to have this missed delivery for the 55,000 cars?

RETTINGER: If they deliver the Model X as expected and the car comes out to the rave reviews that the Model S had, than almost 100 consumer reports rating, it's not going to hurt the company long-term at all. But that is a big but.

Every delay for the model X makes the expectations for that much higher. If there is one problem with that car, if there's a battery explosion or battery leak, it's going to spell big potential trouble.

BOLTON: All right. Jon, thanks so much for your input. Jon Rettinger joining us there, president and editorial director of TechnoBuffalo.

Switching gears puts on regulated energy theme, President Obama going all- out over the next several weeks to build support in Congress for a nuclear deal. Take a listen to a speech that he gave at American University.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: Congressional rejection of this deal leaves any U.S. administration that is absolutely committed to preventing Iran from getting a nuclear weapon with one option. Another war in the Middle East.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Joining me now is Phil Flynn, senior market analyst for the Price Futures Group, also author of The Energy Report. So, Phil, we have alternative energy to talk about, traditional as well, I'd like to start with that, what do you think of the president's remarks?

PHIL FLYNN, PRICE FUTURES GROUP SENIOR MARKET ANALYST & THE ENERGY REPORT AUTHOR: Well, I think, you know, once again, the president is saying my way or the highway. You know, if you look at how he always flames the debate. It's either my way or we're going to have a war, there's no other alternative. And that's not true.

You know, the truth is that there are many other alternatives. Number one, for example, continuing the sanctions on Iran. They seem to be working pretty darn well. That's what brought Iran to the table. But the president always seems to do this. He always sees his vision is the only right one, anybody who disagrees with him is the bad guy.

They don't understand. They want a war. And the truth of the matter is there are other options, there's not just two.

BOLTON: OK. So, as far as that goes, Iran, top six in the world's largest crude oil producers, what is the effect if this deal goes through this nuclear deal on the oil market?

FLYNN: Well, I think we should look at both sides of it. First of all, if it goes through, obviously we're going to be giving Iran what, $58 billion? You know, maybe some of that is going to go into their energy industry to try to bring that back online.

Maybe some of it will go to terrorism. You know, who knows? Because they are the biggest state sponsored country of terrorism. But let's look at the other side. What if Congress doesn't do this deal? What if they reject this deal? And the president is saying, hey, guess what, guys, if you don't get this deal, we're going to war.

What is it going to do to the cost of oil? It may cause a price spike because the markets are going to believe the president and they are going to be afraid that a war is going to be just around the corner. So, it could do a lot of damage, you know. So, I think it's dangerous the way this debate is being framed.

BOLTON: All right. Phil, we'll be checking in with you, I'm sure over the next few weeks. Phil Flynn joining us there, senior market analyst for the Price Futures Group, author of The Energy Report, with us there from Chicago.

Stocks as you know, you heard from Lori, closing off their highs. Apple has had a volatile few days, Bank of America today cutting its price target from 142 to 130, changing the recommendation from a buy to a neutral.

Jason Rotman with me now. He is president of Lido Isle Advisors. He is a bull. Mark Luschini joining me, a chief investment strategist at Janney Montgomery Scott. He is an apple bear. Welcome to you both. Jason, would you buy at these levels? It seems like, yes.

JASON ROTMAN, LIDO ISLE ADVISORS PRESIDENT: Absolutely. Absolutely, Deirdre. I mean, the thing is, I would buy and I would continue to buy. In other words, dollar cost average if the price continues to go down. Here's one major reason, OK?

This is what is not really being talked about a lot, for whatever reason, I don't know. 73 percent of the installed user base of Apple still has not upgraded to the latest models. So, Apple is basically still crushing it in my humble opinion, and 73 percent of the people still have not upgraded.

So, I think at the end of the day, it's going to be a Merry Christmas, it's going to be a happy Hanukkah, it's going to be a happy holiday season for Apple. I think now is the time to -- now is the time to buy on the dip.

BOLTON: Mark, I know you disagree. Again, what are you most worried about with Apple? We know as far as hand set sales in China, Apple is number three, behind Xiaomi and Huawei. Is this your concern or is it something else?

MARK LUSCHINI, JANNEY MONTGOMERY SCOTT CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: Well, it's really two things in terms of my concern. Now, one fundamental and one technical. On the fundamental front, it's one of the things you just mentioned, and that is of course China, in the slowdown there. And obviously with the meltdown in equity prices, the impact on the wealth affect there among Chinese consumers.

On the U.S. front or at least phone sales front is more to do with the fact that perhaps the new disciplined consumer is less likely to upgrade to that new iPhone 6 if they've had a recent iPhone 5 purchase. And as a consequence, may continue to defer that purchase. From a technical standpoint, we've seen no less than three previous time to the price points reaching that 130 to $134 level that the price has been turned away.

And this was the most recent one which in our view, was going to lead to potential irritation in the share price. Ultimately, it turned out to be worse. We turn back our position in the portfolio to $125 about two weeks ago and we stayed sidelined for the time being.

BOLTON: OK. Mark, point well made. Jason, I know as you said, you're still a buyer. Where does Apple go from here? What other tricks fundamentally does it have up its sleeve? Is it Apple TV? Are there certain products that you think will be catalysts?

ROTMAN: Yes. That's a really great question. And really I'm going to respond with two major points. Number one, technically, Apple has fallen below its 200-day moving average, 17 times only since the past 30 to 60 days to rebound above it, I think this is going to be no different.

Now, to answer your question from a fundamental standpoint. We're coming in to a holiday season. Again, 73 percent of the people have not upgraded yet. I adamantly disagree with the fact or the theory that people are less likely to upgrade from 5 to 6, I don't think that makes any sense.

People are going to need to upgrade and Apple is a brilliant marketing company, they're going to have a huge holiday season. I think now is the time to buy for that reason alone.

BOLTON: All right. We will leave it there. We thank you for your time for your insights.

ROTMAN: Thank you.

BOLTON: Jason Rotman joining us there. Mark Luschini as well. We thank you both.

When we come back, democratic Congresswoman Barbara Lee calling on Tim Cook of Apple to release employee diversity data. Our next guest says Silicon Valley companies are being unfairly targeted on this issue.

Then you may be out of luck because of Suck. Forget your credit score? According to a new Facebook patent filed. Your Facebook friend's credit scores could keep you from borrowing money.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Some of the stories we're following for you right now. Debris, including part of an aircraft wing, is confirmed to be from the missing Malaysia Airlines MH370 plane. It has been more than a year since the plane disappeared with 239 people on board.

The FBI is investigating the security of Hillary Clinton's private e-mail server. This is the one that she used when she was Secretary of State. The probe comes days after watchdogs from the state department and the intelligence community asked the Justice Department to explore whether or not classified material was improperly shared or stored on the e-mail account.

Security regulators are approving a final rule that requires public companies to disclose the ratios between annual comp of CEO's and median pay of employees. As you see, consider this change for years, it is finally here.

And Representative Barbara Lee, a democrat from California calling on tech companies including Apple to release federal data on diversity of their workforces. Lee was in Silicon Valley this week turning up the heat on the tech community to hire more African-Americans.

Well, last spring, the tech community did sneak into release details on the demographics of its employees. Yahoo, Google, LinkedIn among the first to publish stats. One of the reasons they did, a push from our next guest.

Reverend Jesse Jackson Sr. is with me now. He is an instrumental voice in this push for diversity. He is with me on the phone. Reverend, so glad you're with us. You have encouraged tech companies to share more information, calling on Congress to backup that call. Why is it so important for all of these companies to share their data in your view?

JESSE JACKSON SR., RAINBOWPUSH COALITION FOUNDER & PRESIDENT: Hey, Deirdre. A lot of these employers are in our country. They're the fastest growth industry and they've been from the government and upon consumers.

We're not sending out Apple sending them out of the top 25 from 189 board members, 36 women were African-American, we have Latinos. And just to last year, about Twitter 49 blacks men, 16 Latinos, Facebook, 1600 employees, 140 blacks, just 7 blacks from the west different employees.

Twitter, I mean, Yahoo have 6,000 employees, 138 are black. So, it's not a pretty picture.

BOLTON: It's not a pretty picture. And even Nancy Lee, and I'm going to look at my notes here, reverend, to read the quote, "Google's director of people operation told the San Jose Mercury news last spring. When we look around at the industry, we think we're doing OK, but it is not something we want to tout."

In your view, what is the number one most practical way that you think that tech companies can improve? How can they reach out to different communities, and therefore, recruit with a wider net?

JACKSON SR: With the set goals, targets and timetables, almost the least accepted federal standard, these comes as CEO 1 and contract compliance laws are very important. The government then land for them to file the yield 1 report. It's just that we should publish again as what they have come in the last year.

But they all have a great difference of people's color from their boards and the women. In the six weeks I went three steps with it, unlike three blacks and three Latinos, employment is around 2 percent. And I think that enforcing laws of fair practices for these companies is important.

BOLTON: Reverend, is it more important to have diversity in the rank and file, or is it more important in management to set an example?

JACKSON SR: Well, both examples, both of the employers, there are qualified people at every level. They spend more time looking for each one of the workers from India, from Asia, than training young people right here at home. And that's a big piece of consideration.

There is no talent deficit. There is an6 opportunity deficit. And besides each of those etiquette which we advocate very much at RainbowPush and engineers, the biggest employee base is now in take.

It's ad agencies, it's marketing. It's non-tech workers, that they are hovering around 2 percent in those categories. Some of them from the exempt from any other obligation, they stand up to what's just and fair.

BOLTON: OK. Well, we're glad to have your thoughts on that. Reverend Jesse Jackson Sr., joining us there from the RainbowPush Coalition.

Our next guest takes an opposite view. Kevin Jackson is with me now. He's a former management consultant to some of the world's largest companies. He is with me now from St. Louis.

So, Kevin, what about this argument that the best people have to be found and perhaps there's just ways to get more people in that original pool?

KEVIN JACKSON, FORMER MANAGEMENT CONSULTANT: Hey, Deirdre. Well, first of all, everything Jesse Jackson just said is nonsense. The fact of the matter is, it's people like him that aren't getting qualified blacks jobs because if you're going to hire a black person, you got to understand you're bringing Jesse Jackson, Al Sharpton, the Department of Justice, the EEOC, the Department of Labor, and everybody else with you to that job. So, that's issue number one. And issue number two...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Just to stop you there, Kevin, what do you mean by that? That in other words, one employee has too much baggage to even focus on his or her job hunt?

JACKSON: That's exactly right. If you hire a white kid, that white kid can't do anything, he can get racist e-mails, calling him cracker or anything else he wants. And he can't do anything. He can go HR, and all he can do is just -- they'll laugh together, but they won't have a lawsuit.

But let a black kid get anything or black person at a company, have anything that isn't even related to him, and you've got everybody Jesse Jackson, and everybody coming to the fore to try to profiteer because that's what's happened in American's business. American business...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: So, Kevin, essentially you're saying if employers are unwilling or less willing to hire minorities because they're afraid of potential lawsuits, in case something goes wrong?

JACKSON: Absolutely. And they won't tell you that but that's a fact. And then the other part of it about what Jesse Jackson is looking at. He gave you all kinds of statistics about how many blacks, how many women, how many browns, or whatever.

How about we focus on how many people are truly qualified for jobs. The fact is, Google, Yahoo, and everybody he said will hire the best person if they're pink, if they're purple, if they're striped. They don't care. And that's the problem that Jesse Jackson has in waging a lawsuit against these people.

It's he knows they want the best people. It's the companies that allow this gangster type of mentality to occur that says you've got to have a certain number of blacks, whites, or whatever. I want qualified people. Business wants qualified people and they don't want the racial strife that comes with Jesse Jackson and his ilk. So, that's all that America is looking for.

BOLTON: So, Kevin, to your point, the H1-B Visas that he referenced and that is to say, that allows U.S. companies to reach out and keep students who are here from India, China, or Russia, wherever, there are 3 to 4 million jobs that go unfilled every month in the U.S. because there is a dearth of either math or engineering or science skills. So, maybe that's where we start is more with education?

JACKSON: Well, the fact of the matter is, if Google, the best people are in the United States, I guarantee you, Google, Yahoo, Apple and all those companies want them. They will do a job fair, they don't care what those people look like, what they sound like, they will translate for them. They'll do whatever it takes to get the best employees.

And if there's 3 million H1-B 1's contrary to what Obama or Jesse Jackson or the race pimps tell you, they will hire them and those people are waiting because they're the best employees. And that's the problem is the - - the education system in America is not producing the best employees anymore.

Instead, what we're doing is we're coddling people. We're saying, hey, use this EEOC guidelines and all this other nonsense that business -- that doesn't further business. Use those guidelines to get people hired but don't hire the best. That's why those jobs are unfilled.

BOLTON: All right. Kevin Jackson, good clear view. We're so glad to have you with us. Joining us there from St. Louis.

So, when we come back, Facebook, your friend's credit, well, they could affect your own. A patent just filed has our next guest second-guessing his friend requests.

And Lexus, finally unveiling video of a prototype of a hover board. Social media is questioning its authenticity. Weigh in, tell us. Is it real? Is it Fake? You can tweet to us @deirdrebolton, to me directly or to the show @riskrewardfbn.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Next time you want to loan your Facebook friends may be important, more important than the papers you give to the bank. Social network filed for a new patent that would allow creditors to assess your creditworthiness based on the credit ratings of the people in your social network.

John Ulzheimer is with me now. He is CreditSesame.com president of consumer education. John, first and foremost, what do you make of this idea? What if I was a musician and my former career, now I'm an investment banker, but if my creative friends are still broke, I'm penalized?

JOHN ULZHEIMER, CREDITSESAME.COM PRESIDENT: Well, the challenge that you face is that there's this hypothesis in the world of social media/risk management that birds of a feather tend to flock together.

And if you have a large or disproportionate number of friends or connections on social media that indicate that they're high risk, then the likelihood of you being high risk, again, in their hypothesis is going to be much more likely, and therefore they may actually consider that when determining whether or not to do business with you and under what terms.

BOLTON: All right. But maybe times have changed, right? And I want to play for you, John, we had Mark Luschini as a guest. He's a co-founder of PayPal. Here's what he told me about the new credit environment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARK LUSCHINI, JANNEY MONTGOMERY SCOTT CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: Credit works fairly well for established consumers' financial products. But if you're a young person fresh off the college bench, you're about to move tax brackets most likely. And the FICO score looks back and says, well, you know, just hold it up there.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, in that sense, we know that Mark Luschini with a firm is actually loaning money to people with computer science degrees and other indicators, that even if they don't have money at that time, they will have it.

ULZHEIMER: Yes, that's right. And it's a very good point. The CSPV defines those people as the invisible. Meaning that they don't have any sort of established credit history, other than probably some student loans and maybe some collections from their former apartment complexes.

And it's true that credit scoring systems are much more effective when you have a long history, a robust credit history to look back onto determine whether you're going to be a subsequent risk going forward than the smaller the credit report.

And if you have no credit report, lenders still want to do business with you. And so, that's when they were going to start looking for the secondary and tertiary types of data sources to determine whether or not to do business.

Look, your Facebook score is never going to replace your Equifax credit report and your advantage score and your FICO score and your Transunion credit report, simply isn't going to do it.

But, where it can be very effective is, for example, my niece who is about to graduate from school, probably has very little credit history and is going want to lease an apartment, is going to want to buy a car, is going to buy a house someday.

And to penalize her because she has no robust credit history, without perhaps, looking how quality her connections are on Facebook. It seems to be a little bit unfair and actually can work in someone's favor. This isn't always going to work against somebody, it can actually work in your favor in many instances.

BOLTON: All right. John, great to have you with us. I should mention as well, Facebook, other big tech companies they filed for patents that they don't use, maybe this is just filing to file it.

When we come back, Disney's stock dropping more than 9 percent. Netflix going to an all-time high, a new media battle is brewing.

My panel guest will tell you which companies as they think will come out on top. Netflix also announcing a one year paid paternity leave and maternity leave for all employees, will other companies follow suit? We'll talk about it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: The first republican presidential debate of 2016 tomorrow night on Fox News. Donald Trump is the most successful candidate, if you measure by social media reads. Speaking of the Donald, some people say the number who watch the debate may, in fact, top the final episode of Trump's last celebrity apprentice.

With me now from Cleveland where the debate will take place is Blake Burman. So, Blake, what's Trump saying ahead of the big night?

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Believe it or not, Deirdre, Donald Trump is actually lowering expectations a bit. You just mentioned that "Celebrity Apprentice," the final episode of the last show had six million viewers, a little more than that.

Some feel the debate here tomorrow night could actually top that. For a little bit of perspective context there, the first primary debates of 2011, four years ago, were about half that, but they didn't have the Trump factor. Why so many people will be tuning in tomorrow night.

Still, though, Donald Trump lowering expectations talking about how he is not a debater at all while these politicians as he calls them are. I want you to take a little listen real quick to what he told Trish Regan this afternoon about lowering those expectations, here it is.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I want to set the bar so low, I want to set that bar so low, you have you no idea. But we'll see what happens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: So, he said, we'll see what happens. He talked about lowering the bar, laughing it off a little bit. We'll see what happens tomorrow night. Donald Trump did say earlier today as well as he has last night that he wants to approach this debate in a civil manner. But he also said, Deirdre, if he's attacked, he would fight back. We'll see when that happens.

BOLTON: Yes. I was going to say...

(CROSSTALK)

BURMAN: Who that happens thought in, how Donald Trump has thought.

BOLTON: ... yes. That seems like likely as in scale of 10 out of 10.

BURMAN: Yes.

BOLTON: Blake Burman joining me there from Cleveland, Ohio. Thank you very much, Blake.

Well, for more on tomorrow's GOP debate, social media power, Matt Witheiler from FlyBridge Capital Partners is here, as is Russ Frushtick, the editorial director at Product Hunt. Glad to have you both here.

So, what do you think about this debate? Let's just talk about it from a media perspective, perhaps a number of viewers outpacing "The Apprentice"?

MATT WITHEILER, FLYBRIDGE CAPITAL GENERAL PARTNER: Isn't really that surprising? I mean, everybody I know who's going to watch and is playing some form of drinking game involving Trump at some point. So, I think that it actually will be a ratings boon for Fox.

BOLTON: All right. And, Russ, from a social media perspective, you heard him say, I want to lower expectations so much.

RUSS FRUSHTICK, PRODUCT HUNTS EDITORIAL DIRECTOR: Yes.

BOLTON: So, do you think he knows he's going to bomb but he's still just counting on Twitter, Facebook and the rest for his messages?

FRUSHTICK: Well, first of all, he's being very humble. I mean, that's what a good politician should lower expectations before a debate and then they come out and make a big splash, I think he'll definitely do that here. Whether it's a successful splash, helping his campaign, I don't know, but he certainly has a lot of social media power.

BOLTON: He does indeed. I mean, and he has this sort of upwards of 23 percent reach, you know, the next candidate is Jeb Bush, around 12 percent. So, love him or hate him. His message and his quote and quote, "Authentic brand," seems to be resonating even with some of it is ironic.

WITHEILER: Yes. I think that's right. I think he's going to drive a big audience, whether you are for him or against him. It's really bringing everybody to the table for this debate.

And so, they will be a tell-tale performance for him, and that will he be able to convince people who, historically, have been anti-Trump to come on his side of the camp it. And it will really depend on how he performs.

BOLTON: Speaking of branding, going a little bit bigger, Disney versus Netflix. If you had to put money on either one, who's your dog in the race?

FRUSHTICK: Disney. Absolutely Disney.

BOLTON: Yes.

FRUSHTICK: I mean, Netflix is a good company and has a good product. Disney is in it for the long haul. If you're look for a long-term investment, they've been building these franchises like "Star Wars" and Marvel for the last 10 years.

BOLTON: Yes. But they pay for that, I mean, it's like $4 billion a pop, $4 million a pop, sorry.

WITHEILER: Yes. No, that's exactly right. It's very expensive but at the same time, they are getting a huge return for that. Because that content that they produced is undistributed on Netflix. And so, when you think about shows like "Daredevil," which is a Marvel property which is owned by Disney that's on Netflix, Disney is kind of taking revenue from one pocket which is the network content pocket and paying it over to Netflix.

BOLTON: OK. Netflix also announcing an unlimited year of maternity and paternity leave, essentially they also have unlimited vacation. But essentially saying, listen, we trust you to be professional. You know what time you can take and when. To me this spoke of the talent war?

FRUSHTICK: It is part of it. I think another part of it is the -- this sort of a very obvious strategy in the Silicon Valley space where it's like, oh, you have unlimited time to take off, so people generally are very conservative with how they use their time.

If you have three weeks, you're going to take three weeks. So, I think this might be a good PR win for them, but also maybe a little bit of gamesmanship in terms of how people use their maternity leave.

BOLTON: Right. In other words, nobody really wants to take more than his or her peer, right?

WITHEILER: Yes, I think that's right. And I think that from a PR perspective, what it's really doing is it's winning Netflix a lot of points with the millennial generation who wants culture and work life balance. And Netflix doesn't want to lose employees because recruiting a new employee is much harder and more expensive than retaining somebody.

BOLTON: All right. Hold those thoughts. We're going to continue the conservation. I'm going to be back with Matt and Russ in just a little bit of time.

Allegations of overpricing, social media activists calling whole foods out again. This time, though, for something as overpriced and zany as what you're looking at right now on your screens.

And with two million views already on YouTube, Lexus's new hover board getting a lot of publicity. Is it real? Tell us what you think. Tweet to us @deirdrebolton, @riskrewardfbn.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Chances are you have engaged with Taboola's content before. The platform recommends editorial and sponsored articles across many highly trafficked web sites. The goal? Help publishers monetize their content while creating a personalized experience for the user.

Co-founder and CEO, Adam Singolda is with me now. Adam, glad to have you with us.

ADAM SINGOLDA, TABOOLA FOUNDER & CEO: Thanks for having me.

BOLTON: I have often heard your company described as a search engine in reverse? Is that accurate?

SINGOLDA: Yes, I think it is.

BOLTON: OK. And for what reason, how does it work, how does it make what I consume better targeted for me?

SINGOLDA: So, you know, I started the company eight years ago living with my parents and trying to watch TV and I couldn't find anything to watch. And I thought, you know people should not be looking for TV shows, TV shows should be looking for me.

And I started the company, you know, with the vision to connect people with content they may like they never knew existed, which is in reverse to what you do with a search engine when you know exactly what you want to read.

So, with us, information hopefully it's finding you before you knew you were supposed searching for it.

BOLTON: OK. And as far as my data, what happens? How do you find me?

SINGOLDA: So, we work with some of the biggest media companies in the world. From USA Today that we're announcing today, Gannett, Business Insider, and many, many others. And at the bottom of the article do you know how you usually see other articles you may like. We do that which allows us to see what decisions are making when they finish consuming the content.

BOLTON: So, in theory, it also gives sellers of products or services better information on how and who to target?

SINGOLDA: Right. So, we're looking at all the information that's out there definitely. You know, all the media companies we're working with and we're trying to -- there are millions of different options trying to unless they second decide what are the two or three things you may like and never knew existed.

BOLTON: All right. Now, mobile is so important right now. I know you have, as you referenced here, the deal with Gannett, how does it all fit together?

SINGOLDA: So, in general, what we're announcing today is it's exciting in two ways. On the one side from the business perspective, we're announcing that we expect to generate between 45 to $55 million in the next three years to come with Gannett and USA Today.

And the second one which is perhaps even more exciting is where with the industry is going where you buy. You know, I started the company eight years ago thinking personalization is the difference between me and you, and I think that was wrong.

If you think about the way you consume the web, think about when you wake up in the morning and you drink your coffee on the big screen, how do you behave consuming the news versus if you're on your way with your mobile from a Facebook app, how is that different?

So, we envision the web, the future of the web to be sort of a dragon with many, many heads. Whereby each head is an experience -- a different experience of the web that is telling not only to me but to me right now.

BOLTON: To the activity that you're currently doing.

SINGOLDA: Right.

BOLTON: It makes all the sense in the world. Congratulations on the deal with Gannett. We're glad to have you with. Adam Singolda joining me there. He is the co-founder and CEO of Taboola.

If you build it, they will come, that seems to be the device and mantra. We're going to show you the new plans for the tallest residential tower in the world.

And then, asparagus grows after allegation of overpricing, social media activists now accusing whole foods of selling $6 asparagus water. Find out how the company reacted, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Elon Musk is saying that storage, the battery business could generate, quote, "A few billion dollars in 2017."

I am back right now with Matt Witheiler and Russ Frushtick. Thanks, guys, for staying with me. So, what do make, we know that as far as the Tesla and deliveries of cars, Elon Musk missed the target. But he's saying, wait, wait, wait, there's my battery business, it's going to rocket. Yea or nay, what do you say?

FRUSHTICK: Yes, I agree that there is more life there. You definitely don't want to get into a fight where you're fighting against manufacturing and the other big companies getting into this electronic -- electric car space. But, you know, that's the issue, like they haven't been hitting their numbers. So, it's not the best production.

BOLTON: Matt, we know that engineers do not hold these metrics against Elon Musk. Almost anyone in the tech community that I speak with would lie down in traffic for him because they say he puts his money where his mouth is. OK, finally, sometimes he makes mistakes on numbers but the spirit is in the right place?

WITHEILER: Yes.

BOLTON: It that good enough for investors?

WITHEILER: I think it's good enough for its employees, it's good enough for investors that the price of which Tesla had priced that. Big question in my mind. It's easy to point to a shiny new object in battery business don't be distracted by the actual numbers in cars, but it's very speculative in my mind.

BOLTON: Yes, because the stock is already up, something like 30 percent year-to-date. So, if you're an investor you do want something back for that. All right. Speaking of a different kind of fuel, whole foods apparently, selling asparagus water, which was essentially three stocks of asparagus in a jar colored asparagus water.

This is supposed to be just in one store brand with California. But hopefully it's really has this PR issues, price gouging nationwide, they're not the only shop I should say to be facing this. Is this more disappointing because hopefully this somehow supposed to be pure?

FRUSHTICK: I guess that's only their brand. They want to portray this pure brand. But like, it also doesn't tell to surprise us. Every time I go to the supermarket there is another crazy fruit and like a jar, oh, it's carry water now.

BOLTON: Yes. You will live to be 700 years old if you drink this. Matt, what is your take?

WITHEILER: Yes, exactly. Didn't you drink it this morning...

BOLTON: Yes, there you go.

WITHEILER: ... before you even go to work? Now, I think that given the problems that whole foods has had in New York with the Attorney General here in allegations of price kind of manipulation on how much they were charging for products, this did not comment a good time for whole foods.

That being said, I'm pretty sure this was a prank and whoever is responsible probably won't take it too long.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: And I look the company's response. If you think something is not been weighed properly, just bring it back. We were joking, right?

WITHEILER: Exactly.

BOLTON: Like here's my half donut that should have been weighed or...

WITHEILER: My half drinks asparagus water.

BOLTON: There you go, there you go. Power and health to us all. Thank you both for joining me there. Matt Witheiler, a general partner joining us from FlyBridge Capital Partners, Russ Frushtick, editorial director at Product Hunts.

Well, move over Marty McFly because Lexus introducing a real hover board. So, they say, tweet us now. Tell us, real or fake, @deirdrebolton @riskrewardfbn. What do you think?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Some of the top stories trending right now at foxbusiness.com. Target, Walmart, 7-Eleven soon may have less junk at checkout counters. Center for Science and the public interest calling for the removal of those items because they cause obesity and can lead to diabetes. Fruits, vegetables, and granola bars are suggested replacement.

On the health theme, Fitbit reporting its first quarterly numbers as a public company. Wearables tech company earnings soaring. The company is selling 4.5 million devices this quarter, up nearly three million from the prior year.

And, Connecticut, the nation's most expensive place to die. New probate fees resulting in relative receiving bills of up to a million dollars last week to settle the estate of their loved one.

Well, speaking of transitions, we do want to let you know that "Back to the Future 2," made some people dream of a real hover board. Lexus is saying it did. Take a look at this video, releasing a full video of pro-skate boarder. They say it's real. Interested tie but it will not be on sale soon.

Thank you so much for joining us on Risk & Reward. Glad to have you with us. Charles Payne is next. Making Money starts now.

END

MELISSA FRANCIS, AFTER THE BELL SHOW HOST: Nice. Deirdre Bolton gets us out of this. Thank you so much.

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: All right. Melissa and David. Thank you so much. We have breaking news to bring you here right away. A senate IRS targeting report has been released. My colleague, Gerri Willis, has been on the story. So, Gerri, what is the latest?

GERRI WILLIS, THE WILLIS REPORT SHOW HOST: So, Deirdre, that's right. We just got report moments ago. And here is what we're finding the big take away, the IRS was delinquent in providing effective control, guidance and direction in the processing of those tax-exempt application for 501-c3 status. That's what we're learning tonight.

And let me tell you, the report describes the culture within the IRS Exempt Organizations Unit. We had no idea how dysfunctional it was. Listen to this. Top management was never aware of five year delays in some of the processing at some of these organizations applications.

In addition to that, people within the unit were improperly trained. They didn't know the kind of material they were looking at, what they were supposed to do, what the law regarding tax-exempt organizations was supposed to be. There was in siding. People were managing folks were halfway across the country, 2,000 miles away, that made it more difficult.

In addition to that, there were people who worked from home four days a week, and it was difficult to get all the information flowing. This made it possible for Lois Lerner because she was very liberal in her outlook on life, it made it possible for her to have her political point of view represented and that's exactly what happened here, according to this report.

They surveyed 1.5 million documents and 32 interviews with IRS employees, staff and others.

BOLTON: So, Gerri, quick question here, I mean, as far as the staff views, what are, for example, republicans saying to this because many feel like, OK, some of the groups that are even right of center were clearly targeted.

WILLIS: That's right. And as you know, the president recently said they were not. But this report says, yes, they were. That the IRS systemically selected tea party groups for targeting, and as I said, Lois Lerner had a big role in this. Orrin Hatch today saying that he found evidence, and he is the chairman of this committee that the administration's political agenda guided the IRS actions; they're calling this gross mismanagement.

When you read the details of how the section was run, Deirdre, I don't think there's a company you cover in technology that is run that way.

BOLTON: OK. And as you said, the president, this could go all the way up to a PR problem for President Obama.

WILLIS: Well, the big question of course has been, has this targeting been directed from the White House? Even though Orrin Hatch concludes that that's what was happening, I saw none of it in the report.

So, we're still waiting to see if that's in fact the case, and that's the big takeaway question so many people have at this time. But let me tell you. Tonight, the Senate Finance Committee painting a picture of complete disarray in this exempt organizations unit.

And I have to tell you, it sounds like they weren't just delinquent and ineffective at controlling and guiding their employees, they didn't know what they were supposed to be doing, it sounds like.

BOLTON: OK. Gerri, we are going to depend on you for updates. In the meantime, thank you very much for bringing us breaking news on that Senate Finance Committee report.

I want to get you to the markets because stocks close higher but essentially went nowhere. If you look at the levels, oil prices slid. We want to get you down to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. Lori Rothman is there. Lori, what stood out to you about today's session?

LORI ROTHMAN, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Deirdre. Well, the hundred-point rally we had early fizzling certainly stood out. So, both said and done the Dow is down 10 points to close at 17,540. You hit the nail with that decline in oil prices. So, it looks like four days the down days for the Dow.

The NASDAQ did post gains, about 34 points by the close. Lot of that had to do with finally a turnaround in shares of Apple. Apple shares up 6/10 of a percent, up for the first time in five days, down 14 percent still since April.

We've been talking about the massive amounts of market value. Apple's given up about $100 billion in that time period. Disney was another weight on the Dow, 24 hours later after disappointing earnings report, disappointing revenue to be exact. Apparently, people are cutting the cord, so the cable business is of serious concern.

Disney also warning of mysterious dollar hit, $500 million hit next year to the company because of our strong U.S. dollar. Twitter shares also hit a new low today. A lot of speculation who will be the new CEO and when that person will be appointed. Off almost 3 percent in the regular session. Also Rico reported that Google, an acquisition by Google of Twitter is highly unlikely.

After the bell, we just heard the latest earnings from Tesla, the electric carmaker shares down around. They've been as low as 8 percent in the after- hours which is better than expected report. But here is the problem, Elon Musk, CEO, lowered vehicle sales expectations.

He did promise 55,000 electric vehicles sold this year and he lowered that mark, 50 to 55,000. So, that pretty much sums up the day, Deirdre. I'll send it back over to you.

BOLTON: Lori, thank you so much. I'm going to pick up right where you left off on Tesla. Lori just told you beat on the top and the bottom lines. But this big question, can Elon Musk's company develop and deliver 55,000 cars, you heard her say. It seems like not.

I want to bring in the president and editorial director of TechnoBuffalo, Jon Rettinger. So, Jon, first and foremost, what do you make of the earnings, we'll talk about production in a minute.

JON RETTINGER, TECHNOBUFFALO PRESIDENT AND EDITORIAL DIRECTOR: Sure. So, I think people were disappointed by not hitting the sales number at 55,000 numbers. Numbers has been touted. We're supposed to have the model x this year, the model x kept getting delayed. Now we're hearing we're going to have it start shipping toward the end of the year.

But we heard blames of making sure that they were -- the partners were going to be able to ship on time. And I think we're losing about 10 percent of your total estimated sales is a big hit for the company.

BOLTON: OK. It certainly is indeed. And I mean, what do you make of Tesla, right? Tesla is supposed to be next generation in Siri. We have Elon Musk touting it as bigger, better, faster, stronger, but, I mean, other car companies can meet their production standards?

RETTINGER: Yes. So, Tesla is one of those companies that is being led by a modern-day Steve Jobs. You have this reality extortion field. People love the company but it follows no sense of logic with how the stock goes. I want them to hear a few things that we didn't get from the earnings call.

Tesla has taken over 29,000 orders for the model x but has given no estimation when its designs is going to go live. Cars are going to ship in a few months. We don't even know what they've ordered at this point. I would like to hear more about their power low, their home battery solution. We don't know much about that.

Tesla has been promising autonomous drive called autopilot in the model x. We're hearing very little about that other than it's been delayed. So, there are a lot of question marks for the company, not to mention the specter of their model 3, the affordable BMW 3 killer supposed to hitting sometime in 2017.

BOLTON: OK. And, Jon, I mean, I know you are a fan, you have you driven one, you have come on the show and talked about it. What does it mean for the future? How much does it hurt Tesla to have this missed delivery for the 55,000 cars?

RETTINGER: If they deliver the Model X as expected and the car comes out to the rave reviews that the Model S had, than almost 100 consumer reports rating, it's not going to hurt the company long-term at all. But that is a big but.

Every delay for the model X makes the expectations for that much higher. If there is one problem with that car, if there's a battery explosion or battery leak, it's going to spell big potential trouble.

BOLTON: All right. Jon, thanks so much for your input. Jon Rettinger joining us there, president and editorial director of TechnoBuffalo.

Switching gears puts on regulated energy theme, President Obama going all- out over the next several weeks to build support in Congress for a nuclear deal. Take a listen to a speech that he gave at American University.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: Congressional rejection of this deal leaves any U.S. administration that is absolutely committed to preventing Iran from getting a nuclear weapon with one option. Another war in the Middle East.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Joining me now is Phil Flynn, senior market analyst for the Price Futures Group, also author of The Energy Report. So, Phil, we have alternative energy to talk about, traditional as well, I'd like to start with that, what do you think of the president's remarks?

PHIL FLYNN, PRICE FUTURES GROUP SENIOR MARKET ANALYST & THE ENERGY REPORT AUTHOR: Well, I think, you know, once again, the president is saying my way or the highway. You know, if you look at how he always flames the debate. It's either my way or we're going to have a war, there's no other alternative. And that's not true.

You know, the truth is that there are many other alternatives. Number one, for example, continuing the sanctions on Iran. They seem to be working pretty darn well. That's what brought Iran to the table. But the president always seems to do this. He always sees his vision is the only right one, anybody who disagrees with him is the bad guy.

They don't understand. They want a war. And the truth of the matter is there are other options, there's not just two.

BOLTON: OK. So, as far as that goes, Iran, top six in the world's largest crude oil producers, what is the effect if this deal goes through this nuclear deal on the oil market?

FLYNN: Well, I think we should look at both sides of it. First of all, if it goes through, obviously we're going to be giving Iran what, $58 billion? You know, maybe some of that is going to go into their energy industry to try to bring that back online.

Maybe some of it will go to terrorism. You know, who knows? Because they are the biggest state sponsored country of terrorism. But let's look at the other side. What if Congress doesn't do this deal? What if they reject this deal? And the president is saying, hey, guess what, guys, if you don't get this deal, we're going to war.

What is it going to do to the cost of oil? It may cause a price spike because the markets are going to believe the president and they are going to be afraid that a war is going to be just around the corner. So, it could do a lot of damage, you know. So, I think it's dangerous the way this debate is being framed.

BOLTON: All right. Phil, we'll be checking in with you, I'm sure over the next few weeks. Phil Flynn joining us there, senior market analyst for the Price Futures Group, author of The Energy Report, with us there from Chicago.

Stocks as you know, you heard from Lori, closing off their highs. Apple has had a volatile few days, Bank of America today cutting its price target from 142 to 130, changing the recommendation from a buy to a neutral.

Jason Rotman with me now. He is president of Lido Isle Advisors. He is a bull. Mark Luschini joining me, a chief investment strategist at Janney Montgomery Scott. He is an apple bear. Welcome to you both. Jason, would you buy at these levels? It seems like, yes.

JASON ROTMAN, LIDO ISLE ADVISORS PRESIDENT: Absolutely. Absolutely, Deirdre. I mean, the thing is, I would buy and I would continue to buy. In other words, dollar cost average if the price continues to go down. Here's one major reason, OK?

This is what is not really being talked about a lot, for whatever reason, I don't know. 73 percent of the installed user base of Apple still has not upgraded to the latest models. So, Apple is basically still crushing it in my humble opinion, and 73 percent of the people still have not upgraded.

So, I think at the end of the day, it's going to be a Merry Christmas, it's going to be a happy Hanukkah, it's going to be a happy holiday season for Apple. I think now is the time to -- now is the time to buy on the dip.

BOLTON: Mark, I know you disagree. Again, what are you most worried about with Apple? We know as far as hand set sales in China, Apple is number three, behind Xiaomi and Huawei. Is this your concern or is it something else?

MARK LUSCHINI, JANNEY MONTGOMERY SCOTT CHIEF INVESTMENT STRATEGIST: Well, it's really two things in terms of my concern. Now, one fundamental and one technical. On the fundamental front, it's one of the things you just mentioned, and that is of course China, in the slowdown there. And obviously with the meltdown in equity prices, the impact on the wealth affect there among Chinese consumers.

On the U.S. front or at least phone sales front is more to do with the fact that perhaps the new disciplined consumer is less likely to upgrade to that new iPhone 6 if they've had a recent iPhone 5 purchase. And as a consequence, may continue to defer that purchase. From a technical standpoint, we've seen no less than three previous time to the price points reaching that 130 to $134 level that the price has been turned away.

And this was the most recent one which in our view, was going to lead to potential irritation in the share price. Ultimately, it turned out to be worse. We turn back our position in the portfolio to $125 about two weeks ago and we stayed sidelined for the time being.
