urn:contentItem:5HJT-T391-JB20-G1YN-00000-00Risk & Reward for December 8, 20152015-12-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:03ZLexisNexisRISK & REWARD5:00 PM ESTErnie Boch, Emily Compagno, Alex Ozols, Gerri Willis, Katie Gorka, Jessica Tarlov, Ashley Pratte, Jessica Tarlov, Kyle Shideler, Katie Gorka, Jim Anderson, Ashley Pratte, Marc SiegelNEWSDomestic120801cb.233Risk & Reward for December 8, 2015Deirdre Bolton

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I'm calling very simply for a shutdown of Muslims entering the United States. I have no doubt that we have no choice but to do exactly what I said, until our country's representatives can figure out what the hell is going on.

We don't know what's going on. You had the World Trade Center one, remember this, you had the World Trade Center knocked down. Make our people are forgetting. You tried -- they tried to knock it down a number of years before that. It's not cons -- unconstitutional keeping people out.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: Donald Trump is doubling down on defending his brand, doing numerous interviews after calling for a temporary ban on U.S. Muslim immigration.

This is Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

A national debate is happening right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Donald J. Trump is calling for a total and complete shutdown of Muslims entering the United States until our country's representatives can figure out what the hell is going on.

(APPLAUSE)

TRUMP: We have no choice. We have no choice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Billionaire backer and Boch Enterprises CEO, Ernie Boch with me now. Ernie, welcome back to Risk & Reward. Glad to have you.

ERNIE BOCH, JR., BOCH ENTERPRISES CEO: Thank you. Thanks for having me.

BOLTON: You're a donor to Trump's campaign -- we love having you here.

BOCH: Yes.

BOLTON: Do these recent comments make you rethink your support?

BOCH: No. No. Because, I don't -- from what I understand, if he really wants to do this, it has to be legislated and, you know, that probably won't happen but he is starting a debate. He is starting a debate and he's getting, he's getting people listening to him.

It's, I don't agree with everything he says but I don't agree with everything anybody says so.

BOLTON: But it sounds like from your point, Ernie, he is doing a service to citizens and -- OK, fine, he's going way out on a limb, but you're saying at least he is getting people talking about issues that are important to our society?

BOCH: Yes, he is. He is getting people talking and I think he should be Time magazine's man of the year, by the way, because of what he has done to the political system and how he has people talking. He's -- he's extreme but, he's -- I like him.

BOLTON: I take your point, and you are not alone. He is comparing himself to other leaders. This comment comes from earlier this morning where he compares himself to FDR.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: What I'm doing is no different than what FDR. FDR's solution for Germans, Italians, Japanese, you know, many years ago.

(CROSSTALK)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: So, you're for internment camps.

TRUMP: This is a president who is highly respected by all. He did the same thing. If you look at what he was doing, it was far worse.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, Ernie, Trump as you know is facing backlash from both parties. Jeb Bush is calling him unhinged. Do you think that, as we said, he is just extreme, do you think he is going to have to run as an independent.

BOCH: No, I don't think he is going to have to run as an independent. I think this is one of the many crazy things that he says that gets people talking, that gets people listening, that gets the conversation going and people concentrating, making awareness.

Do we are -- we are in times that I have never seen before. And I'm somewhat of a history buff and I've never seen these times before in the United States. So, something has to be done whether it's this, I don't know, probably not. But something has to be done.

BOLTON: So, Ernie, because he tweeted out himself, and I'm going to read that "A new poll indicates that 68 percent of my supporters would vote for me if I departed the GOP and ran as an independent."

Now do you think he is doing this because he just wants to throw it back at what he feels like is not support, the opposite of support from his party? Or do you think he is testing the waters?

BOCH: I think he is just, if anything, testing the waters but I don't think he'll run as an independent. I'm not an expert on Mr. Trump, but I don't think he will run as an independent. I think he is going to win the GOP nomination.

BOLTON: All right. Let's listen to some of the GOP candidates who, at least today, do not share your particular view on that subject.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CARLY FIORINA, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: That overreaction is as dangerous as Barack Obama's under reaction. So let's see, we're now going to violate the constitutional rights of citizens because of Donald Trump?

He is mobilizing anti-Muslim sentiment. He is preying on the fears of the American people. It is called rabble rousing.

CHRIS CHRISTIE, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This is the kind of thing that people say when they have no experience and don't know what they're talking about. We do not need to resort to that type of activity, nor should we.

LINDSEY GRAHAM, SOUTH CAROLINA SENATOR: He is a raise-bating, xenophobic religious bigot. He doesn't represent my party. He doesn't represent the values that the men and women who wear the uniform are fighting for. You know how you great America great again? Tell Donald Trump to go to hell.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Well, he said, Ernie, he started conversation for sure. In fact Philadelphia Daily News this is the headline, you may have seen this, Donald Trump, they compare him to Hitler with the new furor on the front page. Did the paper go overboard? That's a big stretch from there to Time magazine?

BOCH: I think everybody is going overboard. I think this is, way, way, crazy.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: This is the point.

BOCH: He is getting people talking. He is doing what he should be doing, he's making people aware of him, what he wants to do. Maybe not like this, but he definitely wants to help the United States handle this major problem that we have.

I think they're doing a lot to derail him and derail him and, you know, they're not doing a great job doing it.

BOLTON: His son obviously remains loyal saying that Muslims support his father.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP JR., DONALD TRUMP'S SON: The driver that you said, this is not someone as I ever met before, very personable guy, because I just wanted to introduce myself, Mr. Trump. I'm a Muslim. And I'm saying, oh, boy, this is going to be interesting.

He goes, honestly, I'm so for everything that your father is saying. Because I went back two years ago to my country, my brother-in-law, came with us on vacation was kidnapped held for ransom. I don't want to see that here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, Ernie, you're a businessman. I want to ask you about this. I actually looked into his golf properties in Dubai and his partner there like you, is defending Trump. At least not going for boycotting saying we are going to leave American politics out of business agreements. So, at least as far as his business goes, even in Dubai, he is not facing any consequence. What do you make of that?

BOCH: I think that's good. I think that's -- that's very good.

BOLTON: Ernie, we thank you.

BOCH: Yes.

BOLTON: Glad to have you with us. Ernie Boch joining me there. We are going to continue because some lawmakers are calling for Donald Trump to quit the presidential race such as republican Congressman David Jolly.

The outspoken congressman will be joining Charles Payne this evening at 50, five- zero minutes, at 6 p.m. Eastern Time. You will not want to miss that.

Critics are blasting Donald Trump saying that his proposal to ban Muslims from entering the U.S. violates U.S. and international law and would never be allowed by the courts.

You just heard one of his supporters and donors, Ernie Boch saying the same thing.

My legal panel is here. Emily Compagno, she says the proposal is constitutional. Alex Ozols says it is not. Emily, on what ground is the plan or anything that looks like it constitutional?

EMILY COMPAGNO, ATTORNEY: I'd actually like to clarify, that on a technicality the Constitution here does not directly apply and here's why. Concept aside of what Donald Trump just proposed, the Constitution applies to every citizen here in the United States and by the bill of rights it also protects even illegal immigrants.

But here Donald Trump's plan is actually about those not yet on our soil, which the United States Constitution does not affect. And secondly, immigration is a matter of foreign policy and national security. And what that means, is that the Supreme Court an all the courts have long upheld that it is immune from judicial review. Meaning that's a matter of administrative law and does not go through the courts.

So, when we talk about the constitutionality of something, I'd like it to be specific. Then here it actually does not apply.

BOLTON: OK. Fair points made. Alex, do you see what Emily is saying? That is to say the Constitution protects religious freedom for citizens. It does not say anything about refugees, immigrants, people who are in the process of being naturalized?

ALEX OZOLS, ATTORNEY: I disagree because it does affect individuals in the U.S. Now, the First Amendment of the U.S. Constitution talks about freedom of religion. And that basically says that if there is a law that discriminates against religion, then therefore that law is unconstitutional.

Now I understand the argument that it's not directly affecting individuals but you have to consider this. What if someone has a lawful visa, and someone else coming in from another country, a spouse. And now they can't come in because they're a Muslim. Now that affects an American citizen.

What if it's a family? What if someone has a job? What if employer is waiting for an individual to come in on a job? This does affect America whether its indirectly...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: But that's different visa with all due respect.

OZOLS: ... or directly.

BOLTON: To me, that's an H1b visa. That's an L visa, that's a different category of quote and quote, "skilled labor," which is an entirely separate process.

OZOLS: Well, Donald Trump said that, he said that this is a blanket. He's not going to let any Muslims in no matter what. He's not going to let Muslims in. He didn't say he was going to make exceptions for employment or family visas.

He said it's an all-out ban. He's not talking about asylum or anything like that. He's not talking about asylum or anything like that. He is saying these individuals can't come in.

BOLTON: Emily, legally, are we allowed to question someone's religious stance when they come here?

COMPAGNO: Well, legally things are set up where actually their religious beliefs are the reason that they're here. And that's why we offer asylum to those who are persecuted for their religion in other countries including certain Muslims.

And, Alex, I understand all of your points that you said, and they're absolutely fair points. But here again, the technicality is that it doesn't apply. So, what we're talking about is something before they get here and the effect on a present Muslim citizen or a present naturalized citizen here who is Muslim, that's not enough to warrant what we're talking about legally in the courts.

BOLTON: All right. Thank you both, glad to have you here. Emily Compagno, Alex Ozols, glad for your input.

We want to get you right now to another legal matter. It is breaking news. It affects health care. Gerri Willis is with me now. Gerri, what is going on with Cigna?

GERRI WILLIS, FOX BUSINESS REPORTER: All right. So, questions being asked tonight about Cigna's commitment to the Obamacare exchanges. Cigna CEO, David Cordani telling Kaiser Health News that the company was committed to participating in the exchanges next year, 2016, but beyond that, the matter is in question.

Now this comes just days after United Healthcare said it may pull out and being in Obamacare was a mistake that cost the company hundreds of millions of dollars.

Cordani telling Kaiser Health News and I should mention, Kaiser is not a political organization. It's a health news reporter. He told them we didn't make money on ACA exchanges in 2014, and we aren't making money in 2015.

I should also note that Cigna is not a big player in the marketplace, 236,000 customers in the Obamacare marketplace. And it is soon be acquired by Anthem. Cordani will stay on as president in that company, but now it's beginning to look a little like a pile-on with more companies starting to say we may not stay in the exchanges. Big questions tonight about how Obamacare continues.

BOLTON: OK. Gerri Willis, thank you as always. Joining me there with that very latest development with Cigna.

Fox News also learning that investigators are focusing on the possibility that Malik -- that Tashfeen Malik, the female shooter in San Bernardino, was quote, unquote, "An operative." We will bring you more details on that.

Also when we come back, a Silicon Valley lender may be behind a California terrorist's $28,000 bank account deposit. We'll bring you everything we know right after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have to find out who gave this guy $28,000, put it into his account. How many other $28,000 checks were made? Are there thousands all over the country. When you say you are afraid, I think you should, you should be afraid of the other side, not my side.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Breaking news. Fox is learning that investigators are say it is possible that the female shooter, you're looking at her photo right now, Tashfeen Malik, was an operative.

Adam Housley is with me from Redlands, California. Adam, what's the latest?

ADAM HOUSLEY, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Yes, Deirdre, a lot of information is coming in right now. There's been some reports also that the FBI is looking at some people that are radicalized here locally.

I just got off the phone with the FBI about that. They say it's not a huge leap to the make that assumption, especially when the regional director came out in a press conference and said that they -- the two terror suspects were talking to people locally who are under investigation by the FBI.

So, you have that element along with international component what you just mentioned. They're telling us that they believe Tashfeen was radicalized overseas, again, not a huge leap. Considering they told us that they feel, in a press conference, they feel "she has been radicalized for some time." That was the quote.

But that she was radicalized overseas that they're looking into her family also being radicalize and that there is the possibility she could ve -- she could been an operative.

Now when I pressed them on that, of course they would not go any further. There is a lot of ways that can go. But that's the investigation right now into her family overseas about, whether they're radicalized, whether there is some sort of operative-type status for Tashfeen.

They also insist that Syed, her husband, was at least partly radicalized here. So, you can then make the connection how to try to put the dots together, and the dots do include information here locally, Deirdre, about the case here and about individuals being looked at very closely by the FBI. Deirdre?

BOLTON: Adam, thank you very much. Adam Housley joining us there from California.

Well, there are new details emerging as you just heard my colleague say on the California killers in various ways. And in this sense, how may they may have funded the attack.

Bank records show that shooter Syed Farook got $28,500 loan from an online lender called Prosper. Now we reached out to Prosper. We e-mailed them, asking them for a statement. They said they prohibited by law from disclosing any non-public personally identifiable information regarding any loan originated to our platform.

All loans originated through the Prosper platform are subject to all identity verification and screening.

With me now Katie Gorka, she is the head of the Council of Global Security. So, Katie, how can this happen?

KATIE GORKA, COUNCIL OF GLOBAL SECURITY PRESIDENT & CEO: Well, this just goes to show that this enemy is very adaptive. We saw that already in Paris, the fact that they were able to carry on their communications without being detected. You know, the thought might be that they were using PlayStation.

This enemy is very adept and very adaptive. And it means we have to be adaptive in our response.

BOLTON: Because we do have in the U.S. anti-money laundering, anti- terrorism, I mean, the banking system in theory is heavily regulated.

GORKA: It is indeed. So, it's a little bit, you know, it really raises questions how this could have happen, when you think about how much scrutiny there is now, post-9/11 of all financial transactions.

Anybody who's applied for a mortgage knows that. But again, it just reinforces that even if we have so many mechanisms in place to monitor, we also have to be aware of the fact that this enemy will constantly find new ways to get around our rules.

BOLTON: And as far as the banks, what role do you see them in? I mean, what role should they be playing? I know for a fact that some of them are going through, they are trying to flag certain transactions but the volume is intense.

GORKA: Yes, that's right. I mean, again, I think they should be held at the same standard as the rest of us, which is see something, say something. I mean, let's use our common sense here. And I hope that this now does alert the banks.

But, again I think that they're operating under tough circumstances as well because the restrictions have become so great, it also has become difficult for them just to carry out their day-to-day business.

BOLTON: So, Katie, we've been speaking about financial issues. Donald Trump earlier questioning terror checks in general.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: We have to find out who gave this guy $28,000, put it into his account. How many other $28,000 checks were made? Are there thousands all over the country? When you say you're afraid, I think you should be afraid. You should be afraid of the other side, not my side.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, Katie, going forward, what can be done whether it's from the banking sector or the tech sector? If there is one thing that could be done to improve our system, improve our security, what is it?

GORKA: Well, I think there's a bigger issue which is that we need to erase the distinction now between domestic and international terrorism. I think that's the single big thing that's really holding us up.

You know, that distinction doesn't hold true anymore. And that's what preventing a lot more effective intelligence being carried out in this country.

BOLTON: Katie, thank you so much. Katie Gorka with us there.

We are going to continue the conversation. She's going to be back with us.

The White House says, going to be speaking to big tech companies about taking a more active role in fighting terrorism. A congressman will be joining us saying he is ready to crack down on Silicon Valley right now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL MCCAUL, TEXAS REPRESENTATIVE: Malik, the female, pledged her allegiance to al-Baghdadi and ISIS in a Facebook posting. We have the computers. We have the devices. We are currently going through the forensics.

They tried to destroy those computer -- computers unsuccessfully. And now the investigation is ongoing to find out what is precisely the connection between ISIS, say in Raqqah, and in the United States and what was going on.

I believe at a minimum inspired, that very well could be directed by this internet communications.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: We want to bring you some breaking news right now. The House approving a bill to bolster the visa waiver program. The vote for 07 to 19, all this came from the democrats. More on this House vote, coming up, republican strategist Ashley Pratte, democratic strategist Jessica Tarlov with me now.

So, first and foremost, Ashley, will this make the U.S. safer?

ASHLEY PRATTE, FP1 STRATEGIES VICE PRESIDENT: I mean, at this point I think what we're looking for are more restrictions when it comes to visas. When we saw what happened with Tashfeen Malik in San Bernardino, that was exactly one of the problems with the K-1 visas at least, which was probably one of the most expensive visas programs. And she was still able to use a fake address; she still had traveled to these countries.

So, I think in placing these restrictions, I think that we will see an outcome that is safer for Americans, but I do think that we need to look out more of a comprehensive strategy overall.

BOLTON: OK. Jessica, to Ashley's point, Malik passed three of four interviews.

JESSICA TARLOV, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Right.

BOLTON: What do you make of this visa program, the idea that the filter will become finer?

TARLOV: I think it's a great thing. I think this is the discussion that we should be having, a more nuanced conversation about looking at specific countries versus, you know, blanketing on, you know, a ban on all Muslims, for instance.

Or Rand Paul proposed a bill last week that would prohibited Muslims for -- sorry, people from 34 countries entering the country, as well as visa waiver country as having to wait 30 days to come here. Which I believe, you know, to be very un-American, and attitude in how we treat other nations and many of them are our allies.

PRATTE: Well, I think you and I can both agree on that too, Jessica.

TARLOV: Oh, great.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: OK. Speaking of agreement...

PRATTE: Good news.

BOLTON: ... it seems as if the White House wants Silicon Valley to take a more aggressive stance. In other words, if pro ISIS, pro terrorist material is out there, here's the latest comment.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: I will urge high-tech and law enforcement leaders to make it harder for terrorists to use technology to escape from justice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: As far as tech companies, what can they really do, Ashley?

PRATTE: I mean, I'm not sure what they can really do, but there's got to be something. I mean, within minutes of that San Bernardino shooting, we did see Tashfeen Malik pledge her allegiance to ISIS on Facebook.

So, I do think that if there are any patterns or anything, if there is any information sharing that's going on, I believe at this point the Islamic state, both the fact that they are tweeting or posting on any social media accounts about 90,000 times or posts a day.

That is a huge amount and that's where they're primarily doing all of their recruiting to mainly a younger audience. And that's why we're seeing a lot of these instances in which they are younger, middle-aged men, sometimes women, and women are tending to be more susceptible to a lot of the radicalization.

So, I do think when we are looking at this, we have to see how significant the role of social media is and what Silicon Valley can do to put some sort of restriction in place or program in place to really filter out what is going on between communication for these...

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: And some have said Twitter is not that strong, for example, if you have terrorist 01 and that could shut down and somebody creates terrorist 02, it seems like that keeps running almost to the extent that some pro terrorists are actually taunting Twitter.

I should also mention making death threats against the current CEO, jack Dorsey. The former CEO, Dick Costelo. So, Twitter responding though, I should read this out, to the president at call to action saying "Violent threats, the promotion of terrorism deserve no place on Twitter, our rules make that clear. We have teams around the world actively investigating reports of rule violation; they work with law enforcement entities around the world when appropriate."

But, Jessica, even if Twitter, Facebook, all the ones that we know begin to be more aggressive, don't we see more encrypted properties? What I want to know is why some Silicon Valley brain kids are not going on sabbatical and working with the government for six months to a year and saying we're here to help. What do you need?

TARLOV: Well, that might be coming. That's a great idea. And I think that also, you know, the government perhaps all too often, has things going on that we don't know about. And I want to have confidence in the fact that they're taking this threat seriously.

And I know that this is going to open up the conversation again about the NSA and Metadata surveillance, I know it's been an issue already in the campaign, it will continue to be. But with 68 percent of Americans feeling uneasy about the president's strategy towards ISIS, and I think it was over 80 percent feeling that there could be an incident on U.S. soil.

This is before the San Bernardino attacks. I'm sure that that's already increased. I think that a lot more people are going to feel all right about their social media accounts being checked and more vigilance over what's going on the internet.

BOLTON: Thank you, both, Ashley and Jessica, glad to have you here.

TARLOV: Thank you.

BOLTON: We are going to stay on the terror trail because new security documents revealed that terrorist have tried to enter the U.S. with Syrian refugees. My next guest is wondering why the White House is silence on the subject.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TED CRUZ, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This makes no sense. We should not be bringing in refugees when on our FBI tells us, we cannot ascertain whether or not they're ISIS terrorists.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: The House just approved legislation to make the filter stronger for the federal visa waiver program. The overall bans people from Iraq, Syria, and the Sudan or those who have traveled to those countries in the last five years from traveling to the U.S. without a visa.

Terrorism expert Kyle Shideler is with me now. So, Kyle, is this a bill like a step in the right direction to protect Americans?

KYLE SHIDELER, CENTER FOR SECURITY POLICY: It's absolutely a good step, but it's really a Band-Aid on a wound we need a tourniquet for, I'm afraid. The visa waiver program has -- has issues, everyone admitted that, that's why we saw such bipartisan support to pass this.

But it's not going to raise any -- it's not going to lift anyone's concerns about refugee screening, for instance, screening on things like K-1 visas, which we saw with the San Bernardino shooting.

These are all still issues in place. So, if -- you know, if this is a view people thank we can do this, and we're done, it's not the case. This is a good start, we need to keep working.

BOLTON: Kyle, Homeland Security chairman Mike McCaul revealed that new security documents proved that terrorists, you just mentioned this, have tried to enter our country as refugees.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHAEL MCCAUL, HOUSE COMMITTE ON HOMELAND SECURITY CHAIRMAN: Tied to terrorist groups in Syria have already attempted to gain access to our country through the U.S. Refugee program.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: So, does it surprise you that we haven't heard more about this?

SHIDELER: It's surprise -- it's no surprise that they're trying -- it's a little bit surprising we haven't heard more about this. There was a desire I think by the administration to paint the refugee resettlement process as beyond approach, vetting was going to be 100 percent. Couldn't possibly go wrong, anyone that was trying to seriously look at vetting for Syrian or other refugees was playing into Islamic state hands.

And now what we're really learning is that Islamic state very much wishes to use the refugee flow in order to move operatives into the United States and other Western countries.

BOLTON: Kyle, some total, when you talk about playing into the hands of the terrorists, it seems like they have one goal, right, which is to destroy. So, anything that goes against that is not in their hands. Am I missing something?

SHIDELER: Their goal is to wage Jihad in order to establish and maintain their caliphate. So, anything that helps them on that effort, they will do, including utilize the refugee flow if they can in order to strike at the West.

BOLTON: We know that Utah, on this point is a assigning a state police detective to monitor refugees. Do you see that as an appropriate precaution?

SHIDELER: If I had limited resources, it may not be the way I would use my detectives. I would be very concerned about new refugees linking up with mosques in my area or Islamic organizations in my area that I already knew had ties to terrorism or Islamic movements.

BOLTON: Well, actually speaking of these ties, GOP presidential candidate, Ted Cruz called earlier for new legislation that would actually ban refugees from settling in the States if they come from a country controlled by a foreign terrorist organization such as ISIS.

SHIDELER: That would be...

(CROSSTALK)

TED CRUZ, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: This makes no sense. We should not be bringing in refugees when our own FBI tells us we cannot ascertain whether or not they are ISIS terrorists.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Although, Kyle, what I'm assuming and what we are hearing and reading about the majority of Syrian refugees is that that's the whole reason that they're leaving Syria is because they don't want to live under an ISIS rule. How do we separate them out?

SHIDELER: Well, we have to have law enforcement intelligence officers who understand this ideology, and they understand this enemy, they know how to ask people questions about their backgrounds, about their history, about their religious and ideological affinities in order to weed these people out.

That training does not exist right now because it was removed from law enforcement and CBP and other officers, Customs and Border Patrol, and other officers have been forbidden from asking these very questions.

So, they cannot ask the kinds of questions they need in order to screen the bad from the good in this refugees flow.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: that sounds like some questions worth bringing back. Kyle, we thank you as always for your input. Kyle Shideler joining me there. He is a terrorism expert.

When we come back, President Obama's says the U.S. air campaign in Syria is working. My next guest says these leaked ISIS documents shows the terrorists have logged some big wins and is also building an empire. He has proof.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA PRESIDENT: Back then in Syria, air strikes are taking out ISIL leaders, heavy weapons, oil tankers, infrastructure, and since the attacks in Paris, our closest allies, including France, Germany, and the United Kingdom have ramped up their contributions to our military campaign, which will help us accelerate our effort to destroy ISIL.

MARCO RUBIO, (R) U.S. PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: Nothing that happened in the speech tonight is going to sweep away people's fear. First of all, we heard tonight that the same strategy that has brought us to this point is the strategy he's going to continue. He honestly believes that there's a coalition fighting against ISIS, this is absurd. There is no such coalition

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: The San Bernardino massacre is showing that U.S. counterterrorism strategy needs to improve.

My next guest says the U.S. has treated terrorism as a law enforcement problem as opposed to a war. The president of the Counsel of Global Security is back with me now.

Katie, thank you for staying with me. So, 20 minutes after the attacks in Paris, the French president said "We are at war." Do we need to make a similar statement?

KATIE GORKA, COUNCIL OF GLOBAL SECURITY PRESIDENT & CEO: Yes, I can't believe we didn't make it long before now. I mean, this is so obvious. And, you know, we continue to treat these acts on American soil like they're isolated cases, we love to throw out the term 'loan wolf' but, no, the enemy has adapted, we're not looking at those grand centrally operations anymore.

This enemy has figured out that it's better off working through individuals who don't need that central direction. This is how they're carrying out their war on our soil.

BOLTON: So, I want to ask you something. President Obama did speak about the terrorist threat saying we will overcome it. And some semantics experts that I have spoken with have said he's doing this on purpose to try to minimize where the French President somehow elevated the terrorist cause. What do you make of this war on words?

GORKA: Yes. I think that's absolutely true. I think President Obama believes that terrorism is a function of U.S. actions in the Middle East. And that now we have a much less bigger role in the Middle East militarily that the terrorism will somehow eventually dissipate.

But that just couldn't be farther from the truth. And I think it's also interesting that he made this distinction in his speech where he said so far, we don't think that these were centrally directed operations. But it doesn't matter because this enemy isn't working that way anymore.

BOLTON: Your point is well taken. Unfortunately, for all of us they have evolved in their tactics as you said. You also noted that the Justice Department is shifting its training, focusing more on Civil Rights than evaluating threats. Listen in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LORETTA LYNCH, U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: Here in the U.S. an incredibly disturbing rise in anti-Muslim rhetoric, the fear that you have just mentioned is, in fact, my greatest fear as a prosecutor. As someone who has sworn to the protection of all of the American people. Which is that the rhetoric will be accompanied by acts of violence.

JEH JOHNSON, U.S. HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY: In the current environment, the answer cannot be to vilify all American-Muslims or to drive them into hiding in this country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: Katie, as a security expert, what is this right mix between security and freedom at this juncture?

GORKA: Well, you know, it's interesting. George Bush apparently was afraid of the same thing. After 9/11, he was afraid that there would be some great backlash against Muslims, it never happened, it hasn't happened, there isn't any backlash.

And so, this hyper concern with how Americans are going to react or we're going to turn anti-Muslim, I just think is just ill-founded.

BOLTON: Meaning if people want to attack us, they want to attack us no matter what we say. Katie, I'm glad you're here. Thank very much. Katie Gorka with us.

We want to give you this breaking news. The U.S. is conducting a serious review of Iran's second ballistic missile test; this is the one in many months, violation, apparently, of two U.N. Security Council resolutions.

According to the State Department and the U.S. Ambassador to the U.N., Fox News first reported the Iranian missile launch yesterday. We wanted to keep you updated there.

We are back in just two minutes with more on Risk and Reward.

BOLTON: Social media tools are used by terrorists and the people citing them. Social Flow is a company that collects and analyzes data that's being shared through Facebook, Twitter, and Snapchat.

Jim Anderson is the CEO, he is with me now. Jim, great to see you. What percentage of social media flow, social media data is either terrorist- related or sympathetic to terrorists?

JIM ANDERSON, SOCIAL FLOW CEO: Well, I don't know the exact number but I have to say it's in fastasmally (ph) small, the challenge with any group is getting an audience. And whether you're be a group for good or a group for terrorism, you've to get the audience.

And so, we do a lot of monitoring of activity, we don't see any significant quantity of that activity.

BOLTON: So, where is the most traffic coming from?

ANDERSON: The traffic is coming from people talk about terrorism. So, the media companies put stories out, there's plenty of commentary, obviously after a terrorist incident. There's a lot of traffic and commentary about ISIS.

And then what we see is over time that tends to taper off after an incident.

BOLTON: Now, ISIS mentions when, you know, across to your point, all kinds of platforms, do you see journalists, do you see -- I mean, who's sharing the most?

ANDERSON: Well, it's everybody. Who's consuming the content and it's both for good and bad. But by and large, you know, with the terrorist incident, it's lots of coverage about the tragedy of it and lots of commentary about how horrible it is.

BOLTON: So, last night, Donald Trump said he would keep Muslims temporarily from entering the U.S.

ANDERSON: Right.

BOLTON: And you sent us a chart, so, we'll show that to our viewers so they can follow along, and it just shows as one of Trump's supporters have said, at the very least he is certainly engaging the public, he wants to start a conversation. So judging by your data, he's successful.

ANDERSON: He has really taken over the conversation. I mean, his traffic as you can see there spiked five times larger than it's been any time in the previous 30 days, so he's certainly got everybody's attention.

BOLTON: So, let me ask you, we have the breaking news as far as polling goes, as you know, he had about 30 percent in Iowa but essentially, has a 32 percent rating as far as New Hampshire goes, and you can see how he is, in fact, widening the lead for New Hampshire, and you can see which maybe - - some people may be surprised, Dr. Carson not even on this first screen, he's down noticeably at 5 percent.

ANDERSON: Yes. We did see some interesting data from Dr. Carson. After Thanksgiving, the Thanksgiving break, for whatever reason his commentary, the comments about him on social...

(CROSSTALK)

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: Just ran out of steam.

ANDERSON: ... just sort of ran out of steam. There was not much activity; it was very notable after the Thanksgiving break.

BOLTON: So, if we can pull up that screen again, which are ranks, so you're not surprised I take it by Trump being in that top spot. But it seems as if Marco Rubio is gaining and Chris Christie, although he was endorsed by New Hampshire's main paper.

ANDERSON: Right. I think the big question is clearly, Trump got a lot of attention with this statement yesterday, the question that everybody seems to be asking and I'm asking as well, has he gone too far? When does he go too far?

Just because people are talking about him doesn't mean it's necessarily positive, although clearly, your polling data, you know, seems to indicate there's at least a core group of people who like what he has to say.

BOLTON: Well, his supporters say, he is starting a conversation. Jim Anderson, thank you for the time. CEO of Social Flow.

Well, this is not fog that you're looking at right now. A 30-car pileup in Beijing. Red alert for smog. Schools and businesses are completely shut. The capital city is issuing its first ever extreme weather warning. We're going to be talking about the health of citizens there.

BOLTON: China's capital city more or less shut down because of pollution. So, in Beijing, schools and business are closed after the first ever red alert. The smog is so thick, it caused at least 33-car pileup, killing at least six people.

Fox News our medical A-team, Dr. Marc Siegel is here, as is Ashley Pratte, back with me. Dr. Siegel, how is the smog this bad, what is it doing to people's health.

MARC SIEGEL, FOX BUSINESS MEDICAL A-TEAM: You know, Deirdre, I'm not a big fan of regulations but there is a lot non-going on in China. I mean, the coal is burning, the oil is burning, the gas is not controlled in terms of emissions, the factories are spewing.

And you know, they -- it's not a surprise. I mean, why I can see the air in New York City and we can't see in Beijing. And this leads to asthma being provoked, long-term risks of emphysema, long cancer. This is a very, very, very serious health issue.

BOLTON: OK. A very serious health issue. Ashley, you just heard the doctor say. He doesn't believe in regulation, but maybe China is too unregulated. What do you make of that?

ASHLEY PRATTE, FP1 STRATEGIES VICE PRESIDENT: Well, the good doctor took the words right out of my mouth because I was going to say I'm not for big government. But it seems like at this point the Chinese government has to step in.

The sad thing here is that Greenpeace was the one who had to come out and say, hey, you, guys, should really be issuing a red alert instead of orange because you're still leaving people susceptible to this poisonous smog that's outside.

And the fact that we're allowing someone, you know, like Greenpeace to come in and make those determinations should be concerning to the Chinese government. They should be doing all they can to protect the people right now.

And we just heard the doctor say, you know, the health risk involved with this. But this is poisonous. I mean, people are walking outside. Schools were still open until they closed them.

And this is something -- I have a friend who is actually in Hong Kong right now working and she said, you know, China is actually pretty disgusting in the sense that the air is never really clean to breathe.

So, this is something that's been going on for a while, and we've seen their president come out and say, you know, we are going to cut carbon emissions by 2030. But are they really doing enough?

BOLTON: Well, as we can see from people there, you can't see them right to second, Ashley, but we're showing pictures of bikers with a mask covering their noses and their faces at least trying to protect themselves as much as possible.

Speaking of health issues a little closer to home, at Chipotle, 80 Boston college students suffered from G.I. symptoms, probably tied, possibly tied to e. Coli after eating at a local Chipotle.

So, Doc, how can restaurants protect the clients held better?

SIEGEL: well, you know, Deirdre, Chipotle is getting a heavy hit. And unfortunately, they pride themselves in fresh and green ingredients but this isn't the first time. The Norovirus has 21 million cases a year in the United States and it spreads like wildfire. And it gets very sick and dehydrated and nauseous.

And the culprit is usually a food handler. So, I think with all of this recurrent problems at Chipotle and they've say it's only the Chipotle near Boston College. But the people that go home from there with this are going to spread it all over the community. They're going to add to all of the cases.

So, I think that we have to take a closer look there at the food handlers and how they're preparing the food there.

BOLTON: So, I'm sure they are going to have a very official internal review, if not external review, but it's basically people not washing their hand. Is that what you're saying?

SIEGEL: Not washing their hands and not being careful when they prepare the food. Absolutely. And wearing gloves, they should be wearing gloves when they prepare the food.

BOLTON: All right. Doc, Ashley, any quotes would you go to Chipotle?

PRATTE: I had Chipotle for lunch today, so I'm kind of questioning that decision right about now, but my hand were washed, so let's hope they did, too.

BOLTON: All right. Living on the edge, courageous, Ashley Pratte,...

PRATTE: Yes.

BOLTON: ... with me there and Dr. Marc Siegel, thank you very much.

SIEGEL: Thank you a lot.

BOLTON: We thank you for joining us here on Risk and Reward. Republican David Jolly calling for Donald Trump to quit the race. He is Charles Payne's guest, starting now.

urn:contentItem:5KR5-HNY1-JBHT-D3Y1-00000-00Risk & Reward for October 23, 20152015-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:03ZLexisNexisRisk & Reward for October 23, 2015LanhamFULL TEXT

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: It is a rally three main indices closing higher up 1.5 percent, Facebook, Google, Amazon hitting record highs.

Welcome to Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

Strong earnings results pushing tech stocks to new levels. Our market bull, our market bear with me now with their next moves. Market bull, Michael Lee, market bear Michael Chadwick.

Michael Lee on the bullish side. Alphabet, formerly known as Google. Amazon, Microsoft all exceeding expectations, is there a worry to you, even as a bull that only three to four stocks are really pushing this rally and everyone else is just jumping on a few winners?

MICHAEL LEE, TIGER WEALTH MANAGEMENT FOUNDER & MANAGING PARTNER: Well, what I would say here is these stocks are going push it higher because they're exceptional, and that's why they're going higher.

Google, if you look at them, they have over a billion users on six different platforms, and they're really just -- they're executing on a really high level now. Valuation with Google as with Microsoft one of the other big tech stocks that traded well today, you can look a little closer at, but Amazon and Facebook are almost impossible to value

And what I mean by that is Amazon is doing $100 billion a year in revenue, and growing at 20 to 25 percent, I mean, how do you put a number on that? And their goal is really not to make money. They're investing in all through it new technology.

And then Facebook, you know, not quickly the same top line of revenue, 15, around 15 to 16 billion, but they're growing the revenue at 35 to 40 percent. So, it's really difficult to value those stocks, but I would say that when you have an exceptional business model and you're best in class that you're going to deserve a premium.

And, you know, they say tech leads the market, I'm very bullish on the U.S. economy. And so, I think this is a good sign for things to come.

BOLTON: OK. Michael Chadwick, what the chances this is a bear market trap?

MICHAEL CHADWICK, CHADWICK FINANCIAL ADVISORS CEO: I think the chances are at a very, very high. In fact, as you said earlier, you've got four or five big names leading the market. Where is the overall participation? And in fact, yesterday, there was 1.7 stocks up for every stock down.

Now, on a big day, where the market is up 2, 3 percent, that's horrible participation. The reality is, those are great businesses. Valuations are out of hand on some of them, others are reasonable. But the reality is the economy runs on more than four businesses, and if we don't get the broad base and start catching up to these hot, hot names, then we're going to have a big bear trap.

And I think people need to be cautious, as Mike said, about valuations. People aren't thinking about valuations. And let's step back two days, what drove this rally? Draghi yesterday, and then China overnight.

So, once again, we're back to people acting like Pavlov's dogs and running on stimulus hopes. We're not running on fundamentals here. We're running on pipe dreams on accomplishing value.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: All right. Well, I agree that obviously there are some macro moves and central banks are being supportive. But that said, at least for the three stocks we're talking about, they did actually exceed earnings expectation.

But I want to stay on the tech stock theme, because it's allowing one founder to give back to his employees. Twitter co-founder CEO, Jack Dorsey giving a third of his company stock to an employee equity pool. That by the way, is worth around $200 million, fittingly he announced it on Twitter.

He wrote, "I'm giving one-third of my Twitter stock, exactly 1 percent of the company to our employee equity pool to reinvest directly in our people. As for me, I would rather have a smaller part of something big than a bigger part of something small. I am confident we will make Twitter big."

So, Michael Lee, do you see this as incentive? I mean, this follows decision to cut jobs at Twitter following Dorsey retaking the CEO position, is this his insurance against other people leaving?

LEE: Well, what I would say is this is a nice sentiment by a very famous CEO, a tech all-star. But let's face it, if it was worth two or three times as much as it is now, why would he be giving it away.

And now I would love to get more stock. But Twitter is a portfolio company, it's going to have to be bought by someone for them to stay in business and I just don't know what that price is.

So, I can't imagine, you know, look, it's a good sentiment but I don't think it's a bullish sign for the stock or whatsoever.

BOLTON: Michael Chadwick does it change your view in any way about the future of Twitter?

CHADWICK: No, I don't think it changes my view of the company but I do love the move by the CEO, and I think more CEO's should be doing that. Because the reality is the CEO's are making so much and their average guy is really having a hard time.

Now, whether the CEO, whether this particular company's stock is worth all that more down the line or its toilet paper is anybody's guess, but I love the concept in the upper echelon of corporate America sharing the wealth with the average employee.

It's wonderful incentive. It lines up everybody's interests and people working a whole lot harder for you when you have that kind of behavior.

BOLTON: Market bull, Michael Lee. Market bear, Michael Chadwick, thank you for joining me.

LEE: Thank you.

BOLTON: We want to bring you now to world and national news, Secretary of State John Kerry meeting with the Russian Foreign Minister in Vienna, Austria. Topic number one, the four-year Civil War raging in Syria.

Russia, by the way, launching airstrikes that are hitting U.S. backed Syrian rebels.

With me now retired General Jack Keane. General, so glad to see you here in person. You told me that the White House National Security team is talking about safe zones and no-fly zones over Syria's airspace. This is a big move and if this is put in place, it's a huge shift in policy, right?

JACK KEANE, FOX NEWS MILITARY ANALYST: Yes, absolutely. A number of us to include Secretary Gates, Secretary Condi Rice, Secretary Clinton have all made these recommendations over the last year or two, Senator McCain goes back about three years.

And what this is as I already understand is a safe zone, we would put largely refugees in there. But once you put them in there, and you have to protect them with some kind of ground force, that would be a moderate opposition ground force that we have been backing, and then you have to protect them with air power because somebody could bomb that.

So, it gets more complicated to put it together and make sure it truly is, quote, "a safe zone."

BOLTON: But it would also, at least avoid what could be called a mistake. I mean, you remember when Russia, by mistake, hit a few targets that it said it was not intending to hit and what if Russian planes and U.S. planes collided, that could start an incident.

KEANE: Well, the good news is that the United states and Russia have had a meeting, a series of meetings actually where out of that came air procedures. So, we de-conflict our operations. So, I'm not too concerned about that.

The Russians will have to make up their mind if they are going to continue to bomb our moderate rebels that the CIA has trained and armed which they have been doing since they've been in there.

BOLTON: So, General, we just saw a picture of the Russian President Vladimir Putin shaking hands with Syrian President Assad. That meeting, a surprise meeting, Assad flew to Moscow and the world is very divided.

Russia and Iran think Assad belongs in power in Syria. Everyone else, Europe and the U.S., said no way. For there to be a peaceful situation in Syria, that guy has to go. What is your stance from a military point of view on how likely it is to remove him and then have peace.

KEANE: well, from a policy perspective, Deirdre, I mean, the reason why Russia is there and the Iranians are there so strongly is because actually Assad, this last year the rebels made a lot of gains and he was in a precarious position, that is over.

They're going to create a buffer zone there, that's why they're pushing back to rebels, they'll create an enclave. Syria only owns 20 percent of the country but they'll make certain that that's a solid 20 percent, and Assad is going to stay in power until such time as the Iranians and the Russians no longer want him in power. We are no longer influenced in that decision.

BOLTON: All right. Well, that is a sober comment, we will hear it, we'll digest it. Retired General, Jack Keane joining me. Thank you, sir, as always. We appreciate your perspective.

To domestic matters, Department of Justice announcing that former IRS official, Lois Lerner will not face charges for targeting political groups. "The probe found substantial evidence of mismanagement, but poor management. But poor management is not a crime."

That is actually a quote, that was the assistant attorney general, Peter Kadzik, who's making that statement. So, this closes a two-year investigation into whether or not the IRS improperly targeted the Tea Party and other conservative groups.

Columnist, Deneen Borreli with me now, democratic strategic Chuck Rocha. Deneen, what does this message send to any party, Tea Party included?

DENEEN BORELLI, CONSERVATIVE COLUMIST: Well, listen, this is the Friday afternoon dump on Americans, Deirdre. And basically, the Department of Justice has essentially said that the IRS can do and say whatever they want to intimidate Americans who want to use their political standards and statures across the country.

They can do and say whatever, and we can't challenge them or we can't hold them accountable. And I think this is really horrible that Lois Lerner was able to use her power in this position to make this happen.

BOLTON: Chuck, for your view, when the Department of Justice says that it found substantial mismanagement, does that require consequences? Is that a slap on the wrist? How do you see this?

CHUCK ROCHA, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: I mean, I think it's what it states that it is. I mean, there's consequences in that she's no longer there. I think that there will probably be reviews, but I think if they use their own words if that you're a pretty bad manager, that will mean you got to go to jail.

I think that there's things that need to be accountable, I think that there's to be accountable to the American people. I think those are our tax dollars. But just because somebody is not good at running their department don't mean that they're a criminal.

BOLTON: All right. Deneen, what -- I know you want to say something, what is your follow-up to this idea of no consequences?
